Data From 06 September 2021, to enter the Republic of Albania, whether by land, sea or air, you must be equipped with:    â¢ Vaccination passport, where at least two weeks have passed from the date of full vaccination; or    â¢ PCR test performed within 72 hours; or    â¢ Rapid antigen test performed within 48 hours OR    â¢ Document / proof proving that you have passed or recovered from Covid-19 valid up to 6 months after recovery;    â¢ These criteria also apply to those travelers who transit through Albania;    â¢ Children up to the age of 6 are exempt from these criteria.    â¢ Albanian citizens resident in Albania who return and do not have one of the above mentioned documents, must be isolated for 10 days and inform the health authority to perform a test at the end of isolation.    ? All passengers who are allowed to enter the territory of the Republic of Albania, in addition to respecting the protocols of international standards that airlines apply anywhere in the world, must also apply these rules:    â¢ Only traveling passengers will enter the airport building, avoiding being escorted by their family members;    â¢ Passengers must respect the social distance of 1.5 meters throughout their stay at the airport;    â¢ Priority is given to the elderly, people in need and families with minor children;    â¢ For more info: https://www.tirana-airport.com/c/116/measures-and-rules/    https://web.archive.org/web/20220301065747/https://punetejashtme.gov.al/informacion-mbi-levizjen-e-shtetasve-te-huaj-ne-shqiperi/

The government adopted two support packages in 2020 for people and businesses affected by the COVID-19 pandemic of a combined size of Lek 45 billion (2.8 percent of GDP) consisting of budget spending, sovereign guarantees and tax deferrals. The first package adopted on March 19, 2020 through a normative act had support measures of Lek 23bn (1.4 percent of GDP) through a combination of spending reallocations, spending increases and sovereign guarantees to support affected businesses. The key measures are: (i) additional funding for health sector in the amount of Lek 2.5 billion (ii) Lek 6.5bn for the support of small businesses/self-employed that are forced to close activities due to the COVID-19 pandemic by paying them minimum salaries (up to two in the case of family businesses with unpaid family members), doubling of the unemployment benefits and social assistance layouts. (iii) Lek 2bn of defense spending reallocated toward humanitarian relief for the most vulnerable which were not used, (iv) Lek 11bn (0.6 percent of GDP) sovereign guarantee fund for companies to access overdrafts in the banking system to pay wages for their employees for up to 3 months with an interest rate capped at 2.85 percent for a maturity of up to 2 years. The government will bear the interest costs. The second package adopted on April 15 2020, includes (i) Lek 7bn (0.4 percent of GDP) fund to pay for a one-off transfer of Lk40,000 to employees of small businesses affected by the pandemic not covered in the first package, employees of large businesses laid off due to the pandemic, and employees in the tourism sector; (ii) a sovereign guarantee of Lek 15 billion (0.9 percent of GDP) to provide loans for working capital for all private companies that were tax-compliant and solvent before the pandemic. The government will guarantee 60 percent of the loans, and interest are capped at 5 percent. As of November 3, almost 98 percent of the overall budgeted direct support measures had been paid out while the take up for the first guarantee scheme was 59 percent and for the second scheme 42 percent. A third smaller support package was adopted on August 13, providing an additional minimum wage to public transport workers who resumed work one month later than the rest. The measure costing Lk135m is accommodated within the existing transport budget.    The government has also adopted tax deferral measures allowing all large companies (except banks, telecommunication, public enterprises and other essential businesses) to defer payment of profit tax for the second and third quarter of 2020 in 2021. Tourism, active processing and call centers can defer payments for the rest of 2020 to 2021. Small businesses with turnover below Lk14m will not pay profit tax for the remainder of 2021.    In September, the government launched an employment promotion program, that aims to cover part of reemployment costs of those who lost their jobs during the lockdown. For formal sector employees the government will cover half of the wages (at the legal minimum level) and the full employersâ share of social contributions for the duration of the program (4 or 8 months). Informal sector employees who lost their jobs during the lockdown, will have the full cost of social contributions (employees and employers share) covered for one year if they formalize.    /web/20220301071254/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

To address the liquidity bottlenecks of companies and individuals, the Bank of Albania extended a temporary suspension of requirements for loan classifications and provisioning to August 31, 2020, enabling clients to ask banks to defer loan installments without penalties. On May 28, the BoA also adopted regulations to allow banks to restructure loans within 2020 without additional provisioning or downgrades for borrowersâ status. Entry in force of more stringent classification and provisioning measures for reclassified loans was postponed by one year to 2022. Out of court restructuring for distressed borrowers under a special regulation will be possible for an additional year until 2022.     /web/20220301071254/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

COVID-19 Testing:    Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Albania? Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within one calendar day? Yes  Airport Covid-19 PCR test:  Tirana International Airport offers a Covid-19 PCR test for travelers. For more information, visit their website.  Public Health Labs:  Currently, to be tested for COVID-19 by the Albanian public health authority one must have symptoms and a recommendation from the public health authorityâs family doctor.  However, private testing labs will perform a test for a fee, and no symptoms or a doctorâs recommendation is required (see details below).  If you have an Albanian social security number, you also have an assigned public health family doctor.  To learn who your public health family doctor is, call the help line at 0-800-4040 to find out.  Tests are free of charge if done by the Albanian Institute of Public Health (IPH).  Private Labs:  Individuals can also arrange private testing by going to a private testing lab. No symptoms or doctorâs order is required to arrange a private test, and no advance appointment is necessary.  According to the Albanian Ministry of Health and Social Protection, there are several private labs authorized to perform SARS-CoV-2 testing for administrative issues. For a full list, please see the Ministry of Health list here.  Hard copy letters of test results are provided within 24 to 72 hrs. You can arrange another method of delivery (e.g.: email or text) with the individual labs.  Stay home and contact the Albanian National Medical Emergency line at 127 if you believe that you have contracted the COVID-19 virus.  Wait for guidance before going to a medical facility.  More information can be obtained by calling the national green line at 0-800-4040 to find out.  Visit the website of the Albanian Ministry of Health and Social Protection and the Institute of Public Health for additional information.  For information on limited humanitarian exemptions, please review the CDCâs website.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220301065252/https://al.usembassy.gov/updates_covid19/

COVID-19 Vaccine Information:    Has the government of Albania approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use? Yes  Are vaccines available in Albania for U.S. citizens to receive? Yes  Which vaccines are available in Albania?  According to Albanian health authorities, the government is currently administering Pfizer-BioNTech, AstraZeneca-Oxford, Gamaleya and Sinovac vaccines.  So far Albania has administered more than 1,500,000 doses of vaccines.  At this time U.S. citizens and other foreign nationals are not eligible to receive a vaccine locally unless they have an Albanian residency permit, an Albanian social security number, and are registered with the national health system. If you have a residency permit and an Albanian social security number, you can register for details about the vaccination process at e-albania.al. Once you register you will be contacted with more information about receiving the vaccine.  Visit the FDAâs website to learn more about FDA-approved vaccines in the United States.  Starting September 1, 2021, vaccination will be mandatory for groups at-risk, including medical staff, teachers, and students, by September 30, 2021.  â¢ Those who will not have evidence of vaccination against COVID-19 will have to show negative COVID-19 test results periodically.  The United States Government does not plan to provide COVID-19 vaccinations to private U.S. citizens overseas.  Please follow host country developments and guidelines for COVID-19 vaccination.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220301065252/https://al.usembassy.gov/updates_covid19/

Educational field    Tests or evidence of a low epidemiological risk  Schools are open to anyone who needs them. If students are in the school building, they must carry out antigen or PCR tests at least twice a week. These tests are to be carried out so often that valid evidence can be presented for each day of the teaching week. If the test intervals are observed, the test result is also valid on the sixth and seventh day after the first test.    Mask requirement  â¢	In the generally accessible areas of the school building or in homes (e.g. corridors), FFP2 masks are still compulsory for teachers and administrative staff as well as for external persons.  â¢	The FFP2 mask requirement in classrooms and group rooms and teachers' and conference rooms for teachers and administrative staff as well as for external persons with proof of a low epidemiological risk (vaccinated, recovered or tested) is no longer applicable.  â¢	Outside the classrooms and group rooms, students up to the 8th grade wear an MNS and students from the 9th grade wear an FFP2 mask.  â¢	A mask does not have to be worn in physical education classes, in movement-oriented classes in the classroom or in dormitories.    For further binding regulations see  COVID-19 School Ordinance 2021/22  and its amendment as well as  COVID-19 Higher Education Act.    Further information can be found on the website of the  Federal Ministry of Education, Science and Research (BMBWF).    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220321195005/https://corona-ampel.gv.at/aktuelle-massnahmen/bundesweite-massnahmen/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220321170229/https://www.sozialministerium.at/Informationen-zum-Coronavirus/Coronavirus---Aktuelle-Ma%C3%9Fnahmen.html

From March 5th, 2022 (up to and including April 2nd, 2022), the COVID-19 Basic Measures Ordinance will be in force nationwide.  At work, there are currently no [general] measures for the workplace. However, in several states, there are still requirements for specific sectors.      There are still requirements nationwide for employees in hospital/healthcare settings to show proof of low epidemiological risk.  In some states, the requirement is higher (for example 2.5G in Vienna).  Restaurants and cafes are open in Vienna but the 2G rule applies (fully vaccinated or recovered, tests are not accepted).     Sources:  https://archive.ph/7RABT [Nationwide measures]  https://archive.ph/HM3ky [Coronavirus: current measures]  https://archive.ph/OoVRp [Overview of the current Corona rules - Vienna]  https://archive.ph/UdG3A [Current measures in Carinthia at a glance]  https://archive.ph/aalil [Current measures in Burgenland at a glance]

At work  There are currently no measures for the workplace.    Health and social sector  Mobile care and support services  â¢	Mobile care and support service providers may only enter external workplaces if they can show proof of a low epidemiological risk (vaccinated, recovered or tested) and wear an FFP2 mask when in contact with customers.    Hospitals and health resorts  The following applies to employees and operators:   â¢	An FFP2 mask must be worn in direct patient contact.  â¢	This also applies to external service providers, resident representatives, patient, disabled and nursing attorneys, nursing supervisory bodies or members of established commissions.  â¢	Taking into account the specific circumstances, the risk of infection must be minimized through suitable protective measures, as far as this is organizationally and technically possible and reasonable.    Retirement and nursing homes as well as inpatient residential facilities for the disabled  The following applies to employees:   â¢	Operators may only admit employees if they can show proof of a low epidemiological risk (vaccinated, recovered or tested).  â¢	Employees must wear an FFP2 mask in direct contact with residents.  â¢	This also applies to external service providers, residents' representatives, patient, disabled and nursing advocates, nursing supervisory bodies or members of established commissions.    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220321195005/https://corona-ampel.gv.at/aktuelle-massnahmen/bundesweite-massnahmen/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220321170229/https://www.sozialministerium.at/Informationen-zum-Coronavirus/Coronavirus---Aktuelle-Ma%C3%9Fnahmen.html

For meetings of more than 50 people, organizers must appoint a COVID-19 officer and develop and implement a COVID-19 prevention concept.    In Vienna: the upper limit for people for events has been lifted. There is an FFP2 mask requirement in closed rooms. If there are more than 50 visitors, a prevention concept must be submitted.    Sources:  https://archive.ph/7RABT [Nationwide measures]  https://archive.ph/HM3ky [Coronavirus: current measures]  https://archive.ph/OoVRp [Overview of the current Corona rules - Vienna]

Gatherings  The following general measures apply to meetings:  â¢	For meetings of more than 50 people, organizers must appoint a COVID-19 officer and develop and implement a COVID-19 prevention concept.     Exceptions to this are:  	o	Meetings in private living quarters.  	o	funerals,  	o	assemblies according to the Assembly Act,  	o	Meetings for professional purposes if these are necessary to maintain professional activity,  	o	meetings of organs of political parties,  	o	meetings of bodies of legal persons,  	o	Meetings under the Labor Constitution Act,  	o	Driving into theatres, concert halls and arenas, cinemas, music halls and cabarets if this is done with multi-track motor vehicles.    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220321195005/https://corona-ampel.gv.at/aktuelle-massnahmen/bundesweite-massnahmen/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220321170229/https://www.sozialministerium.at/Informationen-zum-Coronavirus/Coronavirus---Aktuelle-Ma%C3%9Fnahmen.html

With the 13th amendment of the COVID-19 Entry Ordinance, the following rules apply to entry into Austria, regardless of the country from which entry is made, from February 22nd, 2022:  â¢	3-G  (vaccinated, recovered or tested) â proof required when entering from all countries.  	o	If there is no 3-G proof upon entry, you must register and quarantine for ten days until you receive a negative test result  	o	No countries are currently classified as virus variant areas  	o	The legal minimum interval for a further vaccination dose (â booster â) is reduced from 120 to 90 days  	o	Children under the age of 12 are exempt from the 3-G proof requirement    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20220321170229/https://www.sozialministerium.at/Informationen-zum-Coronavirus/Coronavirus---Aktuelle-Ma%C3%9Fnahmen.html
https://web.archive.org/web/20210523163701/https://www.wienerzeitung.at/nachrichten/wirtschaft/oesterreich/2104654-Kocher-sieht-fuer-150.000-Menschen-Comeback-am-Arbeitsmarkt.html
https://web.archive.org/web/20210523163701/https://www.wienerzeitung.at/nachrichten/wirtschaft/oesterreich/2104654-Kocher-sieht-fuer-150.000-Menschen-Comeback-am-Arbeitsmarkt.html

The low-threshold and comprehensive test offer will remain free of charge until the end of March.    In the future, corona tests will be used in a more targeted manner in Austria. At the same time, everyone is able to take a free corona test if they need it - for example when visiting relatives in old people's and nursing homes.    â¢	From April 1st, every person in Austria will receive a certain quota of free corona tests:  	o	5 free PCR tests per month  	o	5 free antigen tests per month  â¢	In addition, there are of course still free corona tests for people with symptoms.  â¢	People in vulnerable settings such as hospitals or retirement and nursing homes can be tested more often.    However, in order to continue to monitor the pandemic as broadly as possible, more focus will be placed on wastewater monitoring in the future.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20220321170229/https://www.sozialministerium.at/Informationen-zum-Coronavirus/Coronavirus---Aktuelle-Ma%C3%9Fnahmen.html

FFP2 mask wearing obligation  An FFP2 mask or a mask with at least an equivalent standardized standard must be worn:  â¢	When entering closed rooms:  	o	in customer areas of daily life (pharmacy, grocery store, post office, bank, etc.),  	o	when using taxis, taxi-like companies as well as school transport and mass transport,  	o	the associated stations, platforms, bus stops, train stations and airports and their respective connecting structures,   	o	by administrative authorities and courts in the case of party traffic,  	o	of connecting structures of structurally connected business premises and  	o	of religious practice institutions.  â¢	In the case of direct customer or party contact, this also applies to operators, owners and employees, unless the risk of infection can be minimized by other suitable protective measures (in particular technical protective measures such as the installation of partitions or Plexiglas walls).  â¢	It is recommended to wear an FFP2 mask in closed rooms of all means of transport, business premises including restaurants and other places.  â¢	Exceptions:  	o	during the consumption of food and drinks,  	o	for deaf and hard of hearing people and their communication partners during communication,  	o	if this is necessary for therapeutic-pedagogical reasons,  	o	during the logopedic service,  	o	if this is necessary to provide a service or makes it impossible to provide a service,  	o	during exercise and  	o	in damp rooms such as showers and swimming pools.  	o	Children up to the age of 6 do not have to wear an FFP2 mask or an MNS. Children from the age of 6 to 14 may wear an MNS or a tight-fitting mechanical protective device.  	o	Pregnant women may also wear an MNS or a tight-fitting mechanical protective device (medical confirmation must be presented in certain cases).  	o	for people who cannot be expected to do this for health or disability reasons. In this case, another tight-fitting mechanical protective device covering the mouth and nose area may also be worn. If the person cannot be expected to do this either for health reasons, another mechanical protective device that is not tight-fitting but completely covers the mouth and nose area may be worn. Full coverage is when the non-snug fitting guard extends to the ears and well below the chin. If the persons cannot be expected to do this for health reasons,    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220321195005/https://corona-ampel.gv.at/aktuelle-massnahmen/bundesweite-massnahmen/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220321170229/https://www.sozialministerium.at/Informationen-zum-Coronavirus/Coronavirus---Aktuelle-Ma%C3%9Fnahmen.html

According to the decision of the Federal Government of March 9th, 2022, the obligation to vaccinate is temporarily suspended.     Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220310184924/https://www.sozialministerium.at/Corona-Schutzimpfung/Impfpflicht.html  https://archive.ph/tERNe

Health and social sector  Mobile care and support services  â¢	Mobile care and support service providers may only enter external workplaces if they can show proof of a low epidemiological risk (vaccinated, recovered or tested) and wear an FFP2 mask when in contact with customers.    Hospitals and health resorts  In principle, the planned measures must not be disproportionate or lead to unreasonable hardship.    The following applies to visitors:  â¢	Visitors and accompanying persons must show proof of a low epidemiological risk (vaccinated, recovered or tested).  The 2.5G certificate is valid for accompanying persons during examinations during pregnancy, as well as for accompanying patients in need of support.  â¢	Exceptions: Accompanying persons in the event of childbirth, persons accompanying or visiting underage patients, as well as visits to palliative care and hospice patients, for pastoral care and to accompany critical life events.  â¢	The FFP2 mask requirement applies in closed rooms.    The following applies to employees and operators:   â¢	An FFP2 mask must be worn in direct patient contact.  â¢	This also applies to external service providers, resident representatives, patient, disabled and nursing attorneys, nursing supervisory bodies or members of established commissions.  â¢	Taking into account the specific circumstances, the risk of infection must be minimized through suitable protective measures, as far as this is organizationally and technically possible and reasonable.    Retirement and nursing homes as well as inpatient residential facilities for the disabled  In principle, the planned measures must not be disproportionate or lead to unreasonable hardship.    The following applies to visitors:  â¢	Operators may only admit visitors and accompanying persons if they can show proof of a low epidemiological risk (vaccinated, recovered or tested).  â¢	Exceptions are given for persons accompanying underage residents of inpatient residential facilities for the disabled, as well as for visits by palliative and hospice patients, for pastoral care and to accompany critical life events.  â¢	The FFP2 mask requirement applies in closed rooms.    The following applies to residents:  â¢	For new admissions, evidence of a low epidemiological risk (vaccinated, recovered or tested) must be presented.  â¢	An FFP2 mask must be worn in closed rooms in generally accessible places that do not belong to the living area.  â¢	Residents can be offered an antigen test or PCR test by operators at least every seven days, and if they have left the home within this period, at least every three days.    The following applies to employees:   â¢	Operators may only admit employees if they can show proof of a low epidemiological risk (vaccinated, recovered or tested).  â¢	Employees must wear an FFP2 mask in direct contact with residents.  â¢	This also applies to external service providers, residents' representatives, patient, disabled and nursing advocates, nursing supervisory bodies or members of established commissions.    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220321195005/https://corona-ampel.gv.at/aktuelle-massnahmen/bundesweite-massnahmen/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220321170229/https://www.sozialministerium.at/Informationen-zum-Coronavirus/Coronavirus---Aktuelle-Ma%C3%9Fnahmen.html

Belgium operates a colour code that determines entry protocols based on the country of arrival. There are currently 5 colours: green, orange, red, dark red and grey.    - Those who do not live in Belgium who live a country or zone that is not very high risk do not need to get tested or quarantine.     - Those who live in a very high-risk country or zone inside the European Union or Schengen Area who have a vaccination or recovery certificate do not need to quarantine or get tested. Those who do not have a vaccination or recovery certificate have to get tested (PCR) up to 72 hours before arrival. Those who test positive, must be quarantined and are not allowed to travel. OR get tested (PCR) on arrival and maintain a quarantine until the results are announced. Those who text negative can then end quarantine as soon as they get the test result.    - Those who do not live in Belgium who have been in a very high-risk country outside the EU/Schengen area in the past 14 days are not allowed to travel to Belgium except under some circumstances which are explained here: https://web.archive.org/web/20220306174152/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/exemptions/    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220217212028/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/travels/

Wearing a face mask remains mandatory for everyone in the following areas:    - on public transport from entering the indoor areas of the airport, the station, on the platform or a bus, (pre-)metro, tram, train stop or any other means of transport organised by a public authority. Public transport operators and all bus operators carrying out public transport services are not required to cover their nose and mouth, insofar as the driver is well-isolated in a cabin on the one hand, and a poster and/or sticker indicates to users the reason why the driver is not wearing a mask on the other;  - in the indoor areas of organised collective transport (i.e. transport organised in advance with a clear itinerary or final destination and a vehicle with at least 9+1 seats (passengers + driver)), this does not apply to public transport operators, insofar as the driver is well-isolated in a cabin on the one hand, and a poster and/or sticker indicates to users the reason why the driver is not wearing a mask on the other;  - in establishments and places where close-contact professions are carried out. This applies to service providers and customers where there is direct physical contact between the service provider and the customer or where the distance of 1.5 metres cannot be guaranteed between the service provider and the customer for a duration of at least 15 minutes;  - the publicly accessible areas of companies, associations and services;  the publicly accessible areas of commercial establishments, shops and shopping centres;  libraries, game and multimedia libraries;  - in the indoor areas accessible to the public of establishments belonging to the sports sector, including fitness centres and establishments that may remain open in accordance with Article 7, Â§1 of the Royal Decree, subject to items 11 and 12 below;  - in places of worship and buildings intended for the public practice of non-denominational moral services;  when moving around in public and non-public parts of courthouses and courtrooms and, in other cases, in accordance with the guidelines laid down by the Chairman;  - the publicly accessible areas of government buildings;  establishments and places where catering activities are permitted, both for staff and those customers who are not seated at a table or at the bar;  locations where authorised private gatherings and activities in an organised context take place with more than 50 people indoors or 100 people outdoors;  - venues for events of any size, including mass events, authorised outdoor conferences and authorised sports competitions;  trade fairs, including exhibitions;  - other locations where access is organised in accordance with the Cooperation Agreement of 14 July 2021 with regard to the CST. *the indoor areas of schools and educational institutions;  - the indoor areas of the after-school care facilities for primary school children.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220127105912/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/faq/

Schools and universities in the country are attending in-person classes. Face-to-face classes are allowed when providing a physical distance of at least 1.5 m, wearing protective face masks, hygiene on the hands, regular airing every hour and disinfection. Restrictions do not apply to special education support centers.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220314213936/https://bg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  http://web.archive.org/web/20220314214227/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

Conducting face-to-face group classes for children in language centers, educational centers, personal development support centers and other training centers and schools is allowed while providing a physical distance of at least 1.5 m, wearing protective face masks, hygiene on the hands, regular airing every hour and disinfection. Restrictions do not apply to special education support centers.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220321211244/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

Employers and recruitment bodies to organize the work process of employees in remote form (distance work / home work), where possible, allowing the presence of at most 50% of the staff.  Employers and appointment bodies in all administrations within the meaning of Art. 1 of the Administration Act organize the work process of the employees, as:  (a) establish working hours with variable limits and the start of the working day between 7.30 am and 10.00 am, unless this is not possible depending on the nature of the work;  (b) assign remote work to at least 50% of staff, unless this is not possible depending on the nature of the work.  Employers in hospitals, complex oncology centers, dialysis centers, hospices and nursing homes organize the work process by admitting to work only employees with valid documents for vaccination, illness or testing within the meaning of this order. The employer can arrange for a COVID-19 study to be performed with rapid on-site antigen testing. A protocol shall be drawn up for the conducted examination, in which the names of the employee, the result of the test and the date of its performance shall be entered. The protocol is signed by the employer and the respondents. The results are valid up to 48 hours after sampling.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220314214227/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

Employers and recruitment bodies to organize the work process of employees in remote form (distance work / home work), where possible, allowing the presence of at most 50% of the staff.    Employers and appointment bodies in all administrations within the meaning of Art. 1 of the Administration Act organize the work process of the employees, as: (a) establish working hours with variable limits and the start of the working day between 7.30 and 10.00, unless this is not possible depending on the nature of the work; (b) assign remote work to at least 50% of staff, unless this is not possible depending on the nature of the work.    Employers in hospitals, complex oncology centers, dialysis centers, hospices and nursing homes organize the work process by admitting to work only employees with valid documents for vaccination, illness or testing within the meaning of this order. The employer can arrange for a COVID-19 study to be performed with rapid on-site antigen testing. A protocol shall be drawn up for the conducted examination, in which the names of the employee, the result of the test and the date of its performance shall be entered. The protocol is signed by the employer and the respondents. The results are valid up to 48 hours after sampling.    In all markets, marketplaces, bazaars and open-air exhibitions, a one-way traffic organization shall be established, ensuring control of entrants and admitting no more than 1 person per 8 sq m and providing a physical distance of at least 1.5 m between visitors. Workers and visitors are required to wear a face mask.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220321211244/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

The holding of congress-conference events, seminars, symposiums, trainings, competitions, exams and other group events of this nature is suspended. The holding of all mass events, such as music and other festivals, fairs, folklore initiatives and others of such nature, shall be suspended.  Visits to libraries, museums, galleries, cinemas, theaters, circus performances, concerts and other indoor performances are suspended. Indoor team sports are suspended, with the exception of trainings and competitions for registered athletes at licensed sports federations. Sports competitions are allowed without an audience.  Visits to fitness centers, sports halls and clubs, swimming pools and complexes, balneotherapy (medical SPA) centers, SPA centers, wellness centers and thalassotherapy centers are suspended. Visits to gambling halls, casinos and food and entertainment establishments within the meaning of Art. 124 of the Tourism Act, including those to the places of accommodation.  Visits to shopping malls, shops with a net retail area of ??over 300 square meters, bazaars and indoor exhibitions shall be suspended. Exceptions are allowed for shops offering mainly groceries, pharmacies, drugstores, opticians, pet shops, banks, postal and courier service providers, insurers, payment service providers and telecommunications operators' offices, whether they are stand-alone or located in a shopping center type Mall. An exception is allowed for medical establishments and vaccination points located on the territory of shopping centers.  Exceptions to the above apply if all staff have proof of vaccination, COVID illness or a negative COVID test.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220314214227/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

Indoor team sports are suspended, with the exception of trainings and competitions for registered athletes at licensed sports federations. Sports competitions are allowed without an audience. Visits to fitness centers, sports halls and clubs, swimming pools and complexes, balneotherapy (medical SPA) centers, SPA centers, wellness centers and thalassotherapy centers are suspended. Visits to gambling halls, casinos and food and entertainment establishments within the meaning of Art. 124 of the Tourism Act, including those to the places of accommodation. Visits to shopping malls, shops with a net retail area of ??over 300 square meters, bazaars and indoor exhibitions shall be suspended. Exceptions are allowed for shops offering mainly groceries, pharmacies, drugstores, opticians, pet shops, banks, postal and courier service providers, insurers, payment service providers and telecommunications operators' offices, whether they are stand-alone or located in a shopping center type Mall. An exception is allowed for medical establishments and vaccination points located on the territory of shopping centers.  Exceptions to the above apply provided that 100% of the staff at the respective site / persons employed at the event have been vaccinated or have had COVID-19 or have a test result with valid vaccination, disease or testing documents.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220321211244/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

Travellers from a green or orange zone country can enter Bulgaria without quarantine provided they present an EU Digital COVID Certificate showing that the person has been vaccinated against COVID-19, has received a negative polymerase chain reaction (PCR) or antigen COVID test result conducted up to 72 hours before entering the country, or has recovered from COVID-19. Similar documents which contain the same data as the EU digital certificate, such as a U.S. Centers for Disease Control (CDC) Vaccination Record Card, are also accepted.  Travellers from a red zone country can enter Bulgaria without quarantine if they present an EU Digital COVID Certificate showing that the person has been vaccinated against COVID-19, has received a negative COVID test result, or has recovered from COVID-19. Similar documents which contain the same data as the EU digital certificate, such as a CDC Vaccination Record Card, are also accepted.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220314213936/https://bg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Green or Orange zone: All travelers arriving to Bulgaria from a Green or Orange Zone country, regardless of their citizenship, can enter without quarantine if they present an EU Digital COVID Certificate showing that the person has been vaccinated against COVID-19, has received a negative polymerase chain reaction (PCR) or antigen COVID test result conducted up to 72 hours before entering the country, or has recovered from COVID-19. Similar documents which contain the same data as the EU digital certificate, are also accepted. Persons who do not present an EU Digital COVID Certificate will be quarantined for a period of 10 days.   Red Zone: All travelers arriving to Bulgaria from a Red Zone country, regardless of their citizenship, can enter without quarantine if they present an EU Digital COVID Certificate showing that the person has been vaccinated against COVID-19, has received a negative COVID test result, or has recovered from COVID-19. Similar documents which contain the same data as the EU digital certificate, are also accepted. Bulgarian citizens and holders of permanent, long-term, or continuous residence in Bulgaria, who do not present any of the above documents, will be quarantined for a period of 10 days at home or in another place of accommodation.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220321212719/https://bg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Any person who has made contact within 48 hours before and up to 14 days after the onset of symptoms in a patient should be considered when determining close contacts in a confirmed case of COVID-19. If the confirmed case is asymptomatic, contact is any person who has been in contact with the case within 48 hours before up to 14 days after taking the sample that led to the laboratory confirmation.   All close contacts of a confirmed case of COVID-19, at the discretion of an epidemiologist from RHI, are quarantined at home or elsewhere for accommodation and medical supervision for 7 -day period, as of the last contact with the sick person. The monitoring of the health condition of each contact person is carried out by the general practitioner or the respective regional health inspectorate.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220314221945/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/az-sum/kontaktno-litse

No policy change.    Employers should take the following measures:  Ensure that all surfaces in your workplace are clean and hygienically correct. Use alcohol-based disinfectants (minimum 70%).  Clean contact points in buildings at least three times a day, such as door handles, window handles, faucets in toilets and kitchens, cistern buttons, remote controls, power switches, door bells, elevator buttons, reception desks and more touch surfaces used by a large number of people.  Touching contaminated surfaces by employees and clients is one of the main ways the COVID-19 virus spreads.  Clean all touch surfaces at least twice a day: desktops, smartphones and other phones, laptops, keyboards, and computers according to user instructions.  Meeting rooms, trainings and other areas where a large number of people gather should be cleaned after each meeting.  Place hand sanitizers in visible places everywhere in the work environment, especially in public places where people have fewer opportunities to wash their hands regularly. Ensure that these funds are regularly updated.  For hand washing in toilets, provide warm running water and soap, as well as disposable paper towels.  Install waste bins with lids to safely dispose of used paper towels and other waste in toilets and other rooms.  Place the instructions on proper hand washing in a visible place in the toilet.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220228131602/https://covid19.fmoh.gov.ba/preporuke

Provision of services in catering facilities takes place with a distance of at least 2 meters between tables, and catering facilities that organize live music, disco clubs, as well as facilities for similar purposes must implement VPT (vaccinated, ill, tested, rule) with the obligatory observance of a distance of at least 2 meters between the tables.    In the part of the Order for sports competitions, it is allowed to hold outdoor sports competitions in the presence of spectators, in compliance with general hygienic and epidemiological measures, and indoors in the presence of spectators, subject to the application of VPT rules (vaccinated, ) and a distance between spectators of at least 2 meters.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220228132129/https://covid19.fmoh.gov.ba/novost/867/na-snazi-nove-naredbe-kriznog-staba-federalnog-ministarstva-zdravstva

A foreigner who meets conditions for entry to BiH prescribed by Law on Aliens, may enter BiH if he/she at the BiH Border Crossing Points presents any of the following:    negative PCR test or rapid antigen test on SARS-CoV-2, not older than 48 hours if he/she comes from an European country, and if he/she comes from another country, not older than 72 hours until arrival at the border crossing point ofBosnia and Herzegovina,    certificate that a person has received the second dose of vaccine for COVID-19 before more than 14 days before the arrival to a Border Crossing Point of BiH or has received one dose before 14 days and more before the arrival to a Border Crossing Point of BiH, if it is a single dose vaccine,    certificate issued by doctor showing that he/she has recovered from COVID-19 in the previous period from 14 to 180 days until the arrival to a Border Crossing Point of BiH.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220205125253/http://www.granpol.gov.ba/Content/Read/76?title=Stranci&lang=en

No change in policy.    Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in BiH? Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes  Private and public clinics throughout BiH perform PCR and serological COVID-19 tests. Payment is due in full at the time of the test and current prices are roughly 100 convertible marks (km) for PCR and 40km for antigen.  Turnaround of results and availability of testing appointments vary based on the city yet clinics in most large cities have testing options daily and return results within 24 hours.  A list of clinics known to provide COVID-19 testing in BiH can be found on our website here  Public Health Centers (Dom Zdravlja) test symptomatic individuals regardless of nationality, free of charge. To arrange a test, contact your cantonâs health center for additional guidance.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220228142523/https://ba.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

It is mandatory to wear masks at public transport stops, markets / open markets and other places where there is a greater fluctuation in population.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220115120320/https://covid19.fmoh.gov.ba/novost/822/od-danas-na-snazi-nove-naredbe-kriznog-stozera-federalnog-ministarstva-zdravstva-koje-je-usvojila-vlada-fbih

Pfizer, AstraZeneca, Sputnik V, Sinopharm, Moderna  Follow official local sources (also see Local Resources, below) for announcements about vaccines in your area. The United States Government does not plan to provide COVID-19 vaccinations to private U.S. citizens overseas. For citizens of the Republic of Belarus and foreigners who have a permit for permanent or temporary residence in Belarus, there are no restrictions on entry into the country. They also don't need a PCR test. For foreign citizens and stateless persons that without a permit for permanent or temporary residence in Belarus, entry is temporarily limited.  For all categories of citizens who arrived from abroad, self-isolation has been canceled.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220314163208/https://by.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Tests can be obtained at the airport or health clinics in several cities.  It can take several days to weeks to schedule a test, and payment must be made at the time of the test, by the recipient. 11/3/22  There is no government mandate to wear a mask in a school since 17/2/22    In Switzerland masks must still be worn on public transport and in hospitals, clinics, retirement and care homes. But the following recommendation also applies: wear a mask in any situation where you want to protect yourself and others. The mask should always cover your nose and mouth.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220311100556/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/masken.html#-655746524

But the following recommendation also applies: wear a mask in any situation where you want to protect yourself and others. The mask should always cover your nose and mouth.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220311100556/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/masken.html#-655746524

11/3/22    Chapter 4a90 Measures to protect Employees at High Risk  90 Inserted by No I of the O of 13 Jan. 2021 (Employees at High Risk) (AS 2021 5). Amended by No I of the O of 17 Dec. 2021, in force from 1 Jan. 2022 until 31 March 2022 (AS 2021 881; Art. 29 para. 7).    Art. 27a  1 Employers shall enable their employees at high risk to carry out their working duties from home. They shall take the appropriate organisational and technical measures to achieve this.91    2 Where it is not possible for employees to carry out their regular working duties from home, employers shall, in derogation from the contract of employment and for the same pay, assign the employees concerned equivalent alternative work that can be performed from home.    3 Where for operational reasons the presence of employees at high risk in the workplace is essential at all or at certain times, they may carry out their regular activities in the workplace provided the following requirements are met:    a.  The workplace is organised so as to prevent any close contact with other persons, in particular by providing the employee concerned with his or her own room or a clearly separate working area.  b.  In cases where close contact cannot be avoided at all times, appropriate protective measures shall be taken in accordance with the STOP principle (substitution, technical measures, organisational measures, personal protective equipment).  4 If it is not possible for the employees concerned to work in accordance with paragraphs 1â3, the employer shall in derogation from the contract of employment assign them equivalent alternative work in their normal workplace for the same pay in conditions which meet the requirements of paragraph 3 letters a and b.    5 Before the employer takes any measures, he or she shall consult the employees concerned. The employer shall record the measures decided in writing and notify the employees of the same in a suitable manner.    6 The employee concerned may decline to carry out work assigned to him or her if the employer fails to meet the requirements of paragraphs 1â4 or if the employee regards his or her personal risk of infection with the coronavirus for specific reasons as being too high despite the employer taking measures in accordance with paragraphs 3 and 4. The employer may request a medical certificate.    7 If it is not possible for the employee concerned to work in accordance with paragraphs 1â4, or if the employee declines the work assigned in terms of paragraph 6, the employer shall furlough the employee while continuing to pay his or her salary.    8 Employees shall give notice that they are at high risk by making a personal declaration. The employer may request a medical certificate.    9 Article 2 paragraph 3quater of the COVID-19 Loss of Earnings Ordinance of 20 March 202092 governs claims for compensation for loss of earnings related to the corona pandemic.    10 The following persons are regarded as being at high risk:    a.  pregnant women;  b.  persons with the diseases or genetic anomalies listed in Annex 7 who cannot be vaccinated on medical grounds.  11 The following persons are not regarded as being at high risk:    a.  pregnant women who have been vaccinated against COVID-19, for 270 days from the date on which the vaccination is administered in full;  b.  persons specified in paragraph 10 who have been infected with Sars-CoV-2 and have recovered:1.  when based on a molecular-biological analysis for Sars-CoV-2: for 270 days from the eleventh day after confirmation of infection,  2.93  when based on an analysis for Sars-CoV-2 antibodies: for the period of validity of the related certificate (Art. 34a para. 1 let. c of the COVID-19 Ordinance on Certificates of 4 June 202194).95  12 The diseases and genetic anomalies referred to in paragraph 10 are defined in Annex 7 on the basis of medical criteria. The list of these criteria is not exhaustive. A clinical assessment of the risk in specific cases remains reserved and may lead to persons being classed as being at high risk under paragraph 10bis.    13 The FDHA shall continually update Annex 7 based on the state of science.    14 â¦96    https://web.archive.org/web/2/https://www.fedlex.admin.ch/eli/cc/2020/438/en

11/3/22    From 17 February: Almost all measures lifted  From Thursday, 17 February, the following protective measures will be lifted throughout Switzerland:  - mask requirement in shops, restaurants, as well as in other public settings (facilities, venues and events)  - mask requirement in the workplace  - access restrictions regulated by COVID certificate (3G, 2G and 2G+-rule) to facilities and venues such as cinemas, theatres and restaurants, as well as events  - permit requirement for large-scale events  - restrictions on private gatherings    In agreement with the Federal Council, voluntary capacity restrictions in the retail sector and in cablecars and gondolas will be lifted.    https://web.archive.org/web/2/https://www.admin.ch/gov/en/start/documentation/media-releases/media-releases-federal-council.msg-id-87216.html

11/3/22  No Change. Still a ban for those travelling from a high risk country    Travel restrictions remain in force for unvaccinated people from high risk countries.    Who is not permitted to enter Switzerland?  Foreign nationals without proof of a recognised vaccination (see question Â«How can I prove that I am vaccinated?Â») seeking to travel to Switzerland from a SEM high-risk country for a stay here of up to three months without a visa and who do not meet any of the requirements under Â«Who is permitted to enter Switzerland?Â» are not permitted to enter Switzerland. These persons include:    Persons who wish to obtain services in Switzerland;  Tourists, visitors and participants in events;  Persons who wish to come to Switzerland for medical treatment that has not yet begun or that is not regarded as urgently required;  Persons seeking employment or who have been invited for a job interview in Switzerland;  Persons who wish to submit an application for a residence permit.    https://archive.fo/vqA7T

11/3/22  Loss of earnings payments to continue for certain groups of people  Once measures are lifted, there will no longer be a need for most economic support measures. Therefore, claims for loss of earnings as a result of business closures, event bans, reduced working hours and a shortfall in outside care will no longer be possible from 17 February.      An exception applies until 30 June for persons working in the events sector whose employment is significantly restricted due to measures to combat the COVID-19 epidemic. An exception also applies until the end of March for persons who have to interrupt work due to their need to protect themselves. Overall, the rapid lifting of measures should result in a reduction in expenditure of several hundred million Swiss francs  compared to the budgeted amounts.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220218091949/https://www.admin.ch/gov/en/start/documentation/media-releases/media-releases-federal-council.msg-id-87216.html      All employees have protection under the short-time working scheme.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211130074141/https://www.arbeit.swiss/secoalv/en/home/menue/unternehmen/versicherungsleistungen/kurzarbeit-covid-19.html

As of 20.12, the Swiss government pays for tests (both anti-gen and PCR tests) that are needed for a COVID-19 certificate.    Test costs for certificates will be covered again  The Federal Council has also decided that the costs of certain Covid-19 tests that lead to a Covid certificate will be covered again in future. In doing so, he is implementing a parliamentary decision in the Covid 19 law. Rapid antigen tests and saliva PCR pool tests are to be paid for. Self-tests, individual PCR tests and antibody tests are not paid for. The costs of individual PCR tests for people with symptoms of illness, for contact persons and after positive pool samples are also covered. The new test cost system will apply from tomorrow, Saturday, December 18, 2021. From January 17, 2022, everyone who takes part in repetitive tests must also be able to obtain a test certificate.    Only one test upon entry for vaccinated and recovered people  After consulting the cantons, the Federal Council has also adjusted the test regime upon entry, which will apply from Monday, December 20, 2021. Before entering Switzerland, in addition to PCR tests that are not are older than 72 hours, rapid antigen tests that are not older than 24 hours are also accepted. The obligation to have a second test 4 to 7 days after entering Switzerland is waived for vaccinated and recovered people.    http://web.archive.org/web/20211221065541/https://www.admin.ch/gov/de/start/dokumentation/medienmitteilungen.msg-id-86544.html

On 17th February most restrictions were lifted by the federal government    Masks  In enclosed areas of public vehicles as well as in publicly accessible indoor areas of hospitals and clinics, retirement and care homes, people age 12 and over must wear masks. Youâll find more detailed information on the Masks page.    Wearing of masks compulsory throughout Switzerland  The mask-wearing requirement applies throughout Switzerland on public transport and in hospitals, clinics, retirement and care homes. Besides the nationwide rules, the cantons can make wearing masks compulsory in additional areas and situations. For this reason you must always follow the cantonal rules.   Wearing of masks compulsory on public transport and on planes  You must wear a mask in enclosed areas of the following public transport services and facilities:  Trains, trams and buses  Mountain railways, cable cars and chair lifts  Ships and boats  Aircraft (all scheduled and chartered flights taking off or landing in Switzerland)  Note: Masks are compulsory at all times, no matter how many people are travelling. If you refuse to wear a mask on public transport, you may be asked by the transport staff to get off at the next stop. If you refuse to do so, you may receive a fine. You may remove your mask briefly to eat or drink on public transport.     Wearing of masks compulsory in publicly accessible areas  To protect particularly vulnerable people, in certain situations masks must be worn in publicly accessible indoor areas of hospital, clinics, retirement and care homes.   Wearing of masks compulsory at work  Your employer has a duty to protect you. For this reason you should find out from your employer what requirements apply in terms of mask-wearing. You will find more information on the SECO website (in German).  Exemptions from the requirement to wear a mask  Children under the age of 12 do not have to wear a mask (cantonal exemptions may apply). Masks are available in childrenâs sizes. Adult masks can also be folded and the straps shortened to fit childrenâs faces (recommended for surgical masks).  General exemptions from the requirement to wear a mask on public transport and in hospitals, clinics, retirement and care homes. In the following cases, you do not have to wear a mask (regardless of your age):  You can prove that you are unable to wear a mask for a specific reason. Such reasons include, for example, facial injuries, shortness of breath, conditions such as dementia and Alzheimerâs, anxiety when wearing a mask and disabilities that make wearing a mask intolerable or impossible. All medical grounds must be substantiated with a certificate from a doctor or psychotherapist. You will find detailed information in the factsheet from the FBED and FOPH on mask dispensing for certain people with disabilities in the Documents tab.  You are a patient in a hospital or clinic: You can take off your mask when you are in your room(s).  You are resident in a retirement or care home.  Masks in everyday life  In any situation in which you want to give yourself and others additional protection you can decide for yourself whether you want to wear a mask even if doing so is not compulsory. Itâs still recommended to wear a mask particularly in enclosed and poorly ventilated spaces.    https://archive.fo/yREMb

https://archive.ph/ML7FX#selection-143.15-147.20  A travel ban is in place for countries with widespread occurrence of SARS-CoV-2 virus variants of concern (referred to as areas of variant of concern). Transport companies, e.g. air carriers and railway companies, may not transport any persons from these countries to Germany. There are only a few, strictly defined exceptions to this travel ban, namely for:  German citizens and persons who are resident in Germany with a current right to reside in the country, as well as their spouses, partners (if entering Germany from outside the EU or the United Kingdom / Northern Ireland: only partners living in the same household) and minor children  persons catching a connecting flight who do not leave the transit zone of a passenger airport and  few other special cases.  Persons qualifying for these exceptions must nevertheless complete a digital entry registration before entering the country, undergo mandatory testing or provide proof of immunity, and comply with the applicable quarantine regulations for travellers entering the country.

10 December 2021: Germany approves mandatory COVID vaccines for healthcare workers and staff at nursing homes. Medical workers in hospitals, nursing homes, doctors' offices, facilities for people with disabilities, and other health facilities will now be asked to show proof of vaccination or recovery from COVID-19. Only health workers who can provide a medical reason for not getting the jab will be exempt from the mandate.  https://archive.vn/YyP8a    POLICY GOES INTO EFFECT ON 16 MARCH 2022

People are fully vaccinated or previously infected and able to document this, for example with a corona passport,  can enter from all countries without test or self-isolation.    FOR THE UNVACCINATED OR THOSE WHO WERE PREVIOUSLY UNINFECTED:    - Entry from countries in EU/Schengen: A test must be taken within 24 hours after entry.    - Entry from COVID-19 risk countries: A test must be taken within 24 hours after entry.    - Entry from all other countries (high risk countries): A test must be taken within 24 hours after entry within 24 hours after entry. Furthermore, there is self-isolation for 10 days. The isolation may be ended with a negative PCR-test taken at least six days after arrival. Certain travellers (e.g. children under 15) are exempt from test and isolation requirements.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220210053540/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/travel-rules/covidtravelrules

For those who are vaccinated or previously infected, there are no travel restrictions when entering Denmark.    For those are not vaccinated or previously infected:  - There are no travel restrictions if you enter from EU or Schengen countries .  - Those entering from a country outside EU and Schengen, must take a test at a test centre within 24 hours upon entry (self-tests are not valid for this purpose).      Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220306181909/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/travel-rules/covidtravelrules

From 1 February 2022 there are no longer any restrictions in the social and elderly area. Thus there are no longer a requirement for corona passport for visitors etc. and requirements for the use of face mask or shield for visitors, etc. and employees on social services, etc.     If possible it is urged to continue arrangements for the display of corona passport and for the use of face mask/shield in nursing homes and social services with vulnerable residents/users. It is also urged with a continued focus on the test effort in relation to employees in the elderly care and on social services as well as visitors to nursing homes and social services.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220210053301/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

If you have had close contact with a COVID-19 case and you are not vaccinated with a complete vaccination regimen, you should quarantine: if you have had close contact with a patient with COVID-19 or someone suspected of having it without adequate protective measures, from 48 hours before the onset of symptoms, you should quarantine for 7 days staying in your home or place of accommodation, preferably in a room on your own. During the following 10 days after the last contact, protection measures should be stepped up (use of masks, limiting the number of social contacts, etc).  https://web.archive.org/web/20220311053730/https://www.spth.gob.es/faq?tab=2

Public meetings and events are allowed but participants who are 18 years old and older have to prove that they do not pose an infection risk by presenting a COVID certificate stating vaccination or recovery.  For children of 12 of 18, negative tests are accepted for their COVID certificate.  Provided that the organizer ensures that the infection risk status of all the participants is checked, up to 1000 people may participate indoors and up to 2 000 people outdoors.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220306191605/https://www.kriis.ee/en/covid-crisis-management-qa/crisis-management/current-restrictions#mask

On March 15th it appears that all restrictions on gathering have been lifted.  Social distancing guidelines such as dispersion and medical grade facemasks are the only requirement currently.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220321211225/https://kriis.ee/uudised/valitsus-kaotab-homsest-covidi-toendi-kontrollikohustuse-ja-kella-23-sulgemispiirangu  https://web.archive.org/web/20220315215758/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/public-services-and-everyday-life/culture-and-entertainment  https://web.archive.org/web/20220321194839/https://www.kriis.ee/en/covid-crisis-management-qa/crisis-management/current-restrictions#stores

Restriction does not apply to the opening times of stores and services areas of service providers, as well as selling food for takeaway.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220107031211/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/restrictions-in-everyday-life

The targeted curfew has been lifted as of March 15th, there are currently no restrictions on internal movement at this time.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220321211225/https://kriis.ee/uudised/valitsus-kaotab-homsest-covidi-toendi-kontrollikohustuse-ja-kella-23-sulgemispiirangu  https://web.archive.org/web/20220306210600/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/restrictions-in-everyday-life
https://web.archive.org/web/20220321220432/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/restrictions-in-everyday-life

Depending of the country of origin, the list of requirement changes. Travelers might have to get tested, self-isolate and might need to present an imperial reason to be allowed to enter Estonia (work, studying, family reasons, or under a special permit). Those who are fully vaccinated are exempt from these measures.    There's no particular testing or quarantine requirement for vaccinated persons / persons who have previously been infected with the COVID-19 disease.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220306215934/https://www.kriis.ee/en/travelling-crossing-state-border/travelling-estonia/who-subject-restrictions

Exception for Ukrainian citizens entering the country, on humanitarian grounds.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220321215356/https://kriis.ee/en/travelling-crossing-state-border/travelling-estonia/coming-estonia  https://web.archive.org/web/20220321215730/https://www.kriis.ee/en/travelling-crossing-state-border/travelling-estonia/who-subject-restrictions

There is income support for all workers available to them on the second day of sickness, first day is not paid.  They will be paid by their employer according to the average wages of the employee.  Additionally, after the 6th day, benefits are paid by the Health Insurance Fund according to employee's daily income.  Additionally, there are benefits for parents of children where they get 14 days of sick time to care of the child and up to 80% of the persons wages are paid.       https://web.archive.org/web/20220315115525/https://kriis.ee/en/work-life-and-being-away-work/employee/sick-days-certificates-care-leave#care-allowance

There are narrow provisions for debt relief mostly under deferment and grace periods, these all depend on the business/individual working with each banking institution in order to find the best path forward for all involved.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220315115501/https://kriis.ee/en/everyday-life-and-services/services/income-loans-and-financial-difficulties  https://web.archive.org/web/20220315215737/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/work-economy-and-business/banking

Currently there is a site that helps to distribute all the information pertaining to the current restrictions and help measures available.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220315113935/https://kriis.ee/en/covid-crisis-management-qa/crisis-management/current-restrictions

Tests are free if you are symptomatic, however you can pay to have the testing as well.  Testing is generally available.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220306222652/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/coronavirus-infection-close-contact-and-virus-spread/testing-for-the-virus

Currently have web and app based products to help inform and track COVID.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220306223204/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/coronavirus-infection-close-contact-and-virus-spread/hoia-mobile-app

Medical grade facemasks are compulsory when in public indoor spaces, cloth masks are not allowed.      https://web.archive.org/web/20220306210600/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/restrictions-in-everyday-life

Vaccine is available for all persons over the age 5, either covered by the government or health insurance fund.      https://web.archive.org/web/20220315215724/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/covid-19-vaccination/vaccination-plan-and-risk-groups  https://web.archive.org/web/20220315215733/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/covid-19-vaccination/vaccines  https://web.archive.org/web/20220315215739/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/covid-19-vaccination/vaccination-in-estonia

The Nationwide Telework recommendation has now been reintroduced in areas currently experiencing increased levels of community transmission.   The recommendation is for all employees in the public sector to work remotely as extensively as possible if their duties so allow. The Government also recommends that private employers adopt similar extensive remote work practices, recognising, however, that workplaces will determine how to combine in-office and remote work in a way that ensures health security.     Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211216145328/https://valtioneuvosto.fi/en/-/10623/government-recommends-remote-work-in-areas-in-the-community-transmission-phase-until-further-notice

The National Telework recommendation was officially ended on the 28th of February. It is now advised to shift to a combination of in-office and remote work gradually while maintaining the standard hygiene practices.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220306175356/https://valtioneuvosto.fi/en/information-on-coronavirus/current-restrictions

The requirements for entry into Finland include the following:   - a certificate of a full approved COVID-19 vaccination series, OR  - a certificate of having had the COVID-19 disease and one approved COVID-19 vaccine, OR  - an EU Digital COVID Certificate for a COVID-19 disease had less than six months ago, AND  - a certificate of a negative COVID-19 test taken no earlier than 48 hours before arrival in Finland.    These requirements apply to those born in or before 2006. They however do not apply to citizens of Finland, those with permanent residence in Finland or persons travelling for essential reasons. Those who do not meet the requirement are required to have a mandatory covid test.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220106182331/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/travel-and-the-coronavirus-pandemic

A mobile app "Koronavilkku",  is a contact tracing app was produced by the Finnish Institute for Health and Welfare (THL) to help people find out whether you may have been exposed to coronavirus. The app can also be used to send share positive tests results anonymously with those you have been in close contact with.      Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210820141655/https://koronavilkku.fi/en

On return from the Winter holidays (either 21 February, 28 February or 7 March, depending on the region of the country - https://web.archive.org/web/20220216093310/https://www.education.gouv.fr/calendrier-scolaire-100148) the health protocol applied to schools moves from Level 3 to Level 2.     Three main changes now apply:     - The end of the obligation to wear a mask outdoors for elementary school students and staff;  - The possibility of practicing physical and sports activities indoors again without wearing a mask (respecting a distance: contact sports are therefore not allowed without a mask);  - The lightening of the rules limiting social mixing (by level or group of classes rather than by class), especially during break times.    In addition, legal guardians of students who have been in contact with a confirmed Covid-19 case in their class will no longer be obliged to send a signed "Declaration of Honour" that their child has completed the proscribed regime of self-testing in order for them to return to school after isolation, and that testing regime will be relaxed to one self-test rather than two from 28 February.     There are no reported policy changes for colleges and Universities.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220221070953/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education

Some relaxation in facial covering requirements, as from 21 February as schools return from Winter holidays (21 or 28 February, or 7 March depending on region) masks no longer need to be worn outdoors by elementary school students and staff. Face coverings are also no longer required for indoor school physical and sports activities where social distancing is possible (so, contact sports are therefore not allowed without a mask). https://web.archive.org/web/20220221070953/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education    Face coverings are still required on public transport and in some enclosed public spaces such as stadiums, concert halls, and theaters - https://web.archive.org/web/20220221071002/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

Some relaxation in facial covering requirements, as from 21 February as schools return from Winter holidays (21 or 28 February, or 7 March depending on region) masks no longer need to be worn outdoors by elementary school students and staff. Face coverings are also no longer required for indoor school physical and sports activities where social distancing is possible (so, contact sports are therefore not allowed without a mask). https://web.archive.org/web/20220225010222/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education    Face coverings are still required on public transport and in some enclosed public spaces such as stadiums, concert halls, and theaters, but will be further relaxed from 28 February when face masks will no longer be required in places accessible by Vaccine Pass holders - https://web.archive.org/web/20220225003224/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

Vaccination is universally available to people aged 5 and over, with one parent's permission required for children aged between 5 and 11.     Vaccination boosters are available to all people aged 12 and over from three months after the last injection or infection with Covid-19.    People aged 80 and over are eligible for home vaccination visits.     The Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca/Vaxzevria/Covishield and Johnson & Johnson vaccines are authorised for use in France.     Vaccination is mandatory for all staff of medical and medico-social institutions (including administrative staff), supporting services, and those who work in contact with frail people.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220221071212/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

"The vaccine is free for everyone â including recipients of state medical aid (AME) â and without having to advance any fees. Given the public health issue, the lack of medical coverage should in no way be an obstacle to vaccination. Decree No. 2020-1833 of 31 December 2020 published in the JORF of 1er january 2021 guarantees the absence of any remaining expenses on vaccination costs including for people without any social coverage."    - https://web.archive.org/web/20220221071228/https://solidarites-sante.gouv.fr/grands-dossiers/vaccin-covid-19/je-suis-un-particulier/article/foire-aux-questions-la-strategie-de-vaccination

Vaccination is mandatory for all those who work in contact with frail people. Thus, since September 15, 2021, the following must be vaccinated:    - all staff (including administrative staff) of health institutions, medico-social institutions (EHPAD, USLD, autonomous residences, disability structures with or without accommodation and including non-medicalized), social institutions attached to a health institution (LHSS, LAM, CSAPA, CAARUD, CLAT, CEGGID);  - home helpers working with people affecting APA or PCH, in home services or as employees of individual employers;  - staff of medical transport companies (including taxis under agreement);  - all professions in Book IV of the CSP, whether or not under agreement, and professions for the use of titles, as well as their employees (e.g. medical secretaries, dental assistants);  - all health students;  - SDIS-Firefighters (professionals and volunteers);  - occupational health service personnel.    Persons justifying a contraindication to vaccination are exempt from the vaccination obligation.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220221071212/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

The COVID pass in Scotland has now ended effective 28 Feb 2022. However, businesses in Scotland are still required to take customer details for contact tracing, keep screens and social distancing in place until 21 March 2022.     https://archive.ph/mfA03  https://archive.ph/4EPCT

As of 21 March 2022, Scotland has removed all remaining limitations to businesses. Screens, social distancing and customer information for contract tracing are no longer required.       https://archive.ph/4EPCT

With the removal of the COVID pass in Scotland on 28 Feb 2022, there are no longer any limits to public events or gatherings except that facemask requirements are still in place in Scotland until at least early April     https://archive.ph/4EPCT

24 February    Fully vaccinated: Before you travel to England you must complete a passenger locator form. You need to do this in the 48 hours before you arrive in England. 22/3/22  Proof of Vaccination or Negative COVID Test Required for Most Businesses and Public Services:  As of Monday, November 22, 2021, the Government of Greece has restricted access for unvaccinated individuals to many categories of businesses and public services if they cannot prove vaccination or recovery from COVID-19.  Customers seeking access to these facilities are required to present a COVID-19 vaccination certificate or documentation of recovery from COVID-19.  Under the new rules, unvaccinated adults:  Cannot access/enter: Enclosed eating areas, entertainment facilities (cinemas, theaters), museums, exhibition centers, fitness centers and sports venues. These facilities may be accessed only by those who are fully vaccinated or have documentation of recovery from COVID-19.  Can enter only with a negative lab rapid test or PCR test: Unvaccinated individuals seeking access to churches, schools, public and private sector places of work, retail shops, hair salons, or outdoor eating areas may enter by presenting a negative laboratory rapid test no older than 48 hours OR a PCR test no older than 72 hours.  Can enter with no documentation required: Unvaccinated individuals can enter supermarkets, bakeries, sweet shops, pharmacies and urban public transportation.  Children aged 4 to 17 may access the top two categories of facilities with a negative self-test taken within the last 24 hours, documented via the Self-Test Declaration form. Children under four do not need to show any documentation.    Masks Still Required; Other Restrictions Still in Effect:  Greek authorities continue to enforce other restrictions to prevent the spread of COVID-19, including restrictions on certain business and entertainment operations, restrictions on the size of gatherings, and capacity limitations for public transport and businesses. As of December 24th at 6:00am masks are mandatory in all indoor spaces. As of March 5th, Greece will no longer require masks to be worn when outdoors, though masks are recommended in crowded, poorly ventilated areas and by the unvaccinated. Double mask or high protection-type (such as an N95) mask is required in supermarkets and on public transportation.  Additional information is available in English at travel.gov.gr and in Greek at the Civil Protection website and the Greek governmentâs COVID-19 Measures website.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220320124858/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
