22/3/22  Some restrictions in place for all events    As restrictions may vary, you should check the latest local guidance.    Proof of vaccination is required to enter public spaces such as shops, restaurants (indoor and outdoor) and museums. You should be prepared to demonstrate your proof of vaccination and present ID (passport or Greek Residence card) when asked. If you are not fully vaccinated (including children), see Unvaccinated in Greece;  You must use a facemask in all indoor public and communal spaces. In certain areas, such as in supermarkets and pharmacies, and on public transport, you will be required to wear either double masks (at least one of which should be surgical), or an N95/FFP2 mask.    Restricted numbers are in place for churches and religious services;  Unless all passengers are members of the same family, a maximum of 3 persons are permitted to travel in a taxi or other private vehicle with up to 7 seats, or 4 persons in a private vehicle with up to 9 seats;  The Greek government âstrongly recommendsâ that people self-test before any outing.    https://web.archive.org/web/2/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/greece/coronavirus#:~:text=Unvaccinated%20in%20Greece,-If%20you%20have&text=You%20will%20not%20be%20allowed,shops%20and%20restaurants%20(outdoors)%3B

22/3/22  Archaeological sites are open to visitors. The ones over 18 years of age are required to show a certificate of vaccination or illness (up to 3 months after illness) or a negative PCR test done up to 72 hours before entering or a rapid test taken up to 48 hours before their visit, with identity check. Minors from 4-17 years old, who are not in possession of any of the above documents, must show a negative self-test done up to 24 hours before, stating their self-test result on the following pdf, which can be downloaded here. Visitors can enter in groups of up to twenty (20) people (unless they are families), and during their stay they must wear a mask and observe physical distancing. The number increases to up to 40 people where groups with a guide are concerned, provided that visitors show any one of the documents required for entrance, as described above.    https://web.archive.org/web/2/https://greecehealthfirst.gr/

22/3/22  In order to deal with the spread of the coronavirus SARS COV 2, the following public health protection measures per field of activity are extended until Monday, February 21, 2022 at 06:00:    Transportation    	-Towards public transport [public buses (urban KTEL or KTEL buses SA, long-distance KTEL or KTEL buses, individual bus routes), tourist buses and special tourist buses for private, open or closed city, and public transport buses, buses under the jurisdiction of OASA SA and OASTH SA, means of fixed orbit under the jurisdiction of STASY SA, railway, lifts (cable cars)], operation with a maximum occupancy of eighty-five percent (85%) and with mandatory use of high or N95) or alternatively double mask (surgical and fabric).  -Up to five (5) passengers in addition to the driver in passenger cars for private use (E.I.X.) up to seven (7) seats.    -Up to seven (7) passengers in addition to the driver in passenger cars for private use (E.I.X.) up to nine (9) seats.    -Up to three (3) people in addition to the driver in the double cabins, mixed use and VAN type vehicles that circulate according to no. 61512/2900 / 11.12.2002 decision of the Minister of Transport and Communications (? '1548).    -Up to five (5) passengers, in addition to the driver in public passenger vehicles (E.D.X., Special Lease) and private passenger (E.I.X.) vehicles with driver of law 4093/2012 (A 222) up to seven (7) seats.    -Up to seven (7) passengers, in addition to the driver in public use passenger vehicles (E.D.X. Special Lease) and private passenger (E.I.X.) vehicles with driver of law 4093/2012 up to nine ( 9) positions.    - Exceeding the passenger limit is allowed only if the vehicle is driven by a) exclusively parents with their children. In case the children are adults, the confirmation of this assistance is made by presenting a police ID or other official document (passport or driver's license) or b) a person who needs help from a second passenger to move.  Students who are served by taxi in non-urban areas, for their transfer to the school, are allowed to travel up to four (4) people, upon presentation of a relevant certificate from the school principal. The possibility of the previous paragraph is provided, by presenting a corresponding certificate, for the cases of teachers in non-urban areas, who are served either by taxi or by vehicle of one of the teachers.  Exemption from the obligation to use a mask in E.I.X. when only the driver, spouses / cohabitants and first and second degree relatives are on board.  Numerical / quantitative restrictions on travel concern the place / point of departure or internal movement.    Travelers who are fully vaccinated or ill within the meaning of paragraphs 2 and 3 of Article 9, respectively, regardless of destination and by all means of transport, if they operate routes where the point of embarkation or disembarkation is outside the boundaries of the Regional Unit where they have show their registered office: a) vaccination certificate, according to par. 2 of article 9, or b) disease certificate, according to par. 3 of article 9.    Travelers who are not fully vaccinated or ill within the meaning of paragraphs 2 and 3 of Article 9, respectively, regardless of destination and by all means of transport, if they operate routes where the embarkation or disembarkation point is outside the boundaries of the Regional Unit have their headquarters, are subjected to a diagnostic test for SARS COV-2 coronavirus (PCR or rapid test), according to par. 3 of article 9, in private diagnostic laboratories, as defined in p.d. 84/2001 (A '70), or in private clinics or in pharmacies or in a private doctor, at their own expense.    Minors from four (4) to seventeen (17) years old may, alternatively, submit a negative self-diagnosis statement (selftest), in accordance with paragraphs 3 and 4 of article 9.    Government Gazette B 607/2022    https://web.archive.org/web/20220322081234/https://covid19.gov.gr/ektakta-metra-prostasias-tis-dimosias-ygeias-apo-ton-kindyno-peraitero-diasporas-tou-koronoiou-sars-cov-2-sto-synolo-tis-epikrateias-tomeas-metaforon/

22/3/22  Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? No  All passengers traveling to mainland and island destinations by any transport means (train, bus, plane, or ship), must provide the following documents, depending on their age group, as described on the GreeceHealthFirst.gr website:  Individuals aged 12 and above:  Proof of full vaccination at least 14 days prior to travel; or  A negative PCR test no older than 72 hours; or  A negative antigen (rapid) test no older than 48 hours; or  Documentation by a health care professional of recovery from COVID-19 within the previous 2-9 months.  Minors from 4 to 11 years old:  Any of the documents listed above for adults; or  A self-test taken no more than 24 hours before boarding. Self-test results must be reported by printing and filling out the Self-Test Declaration form.  Passengers traveling to Greek islands must fill in the Pre-boarding Health Declaration questionnaire (on their cell phone/tablet or on paper) within 24 hrs before their embarkation.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220320124858/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

COVID-19 tests are available at many major hospitals in Greece, as well as the Athens Eleftherios Venizelos Airport (at Arrivals level between entrances 2-3; see FAQ for more details). Testing is paid by the individual being tested.  The cost for COVID-19 PCR tests is capped at 47 euros, and for rapid antigen tests at 10 euros, though additional charges may apply for testing at home or other circumstances.  Patients needing COVID-19 tests or exhibiting possible symptoms may contact the COVID-19 hotline at 1135 for guidance on testing and referral for medical care.  Travelers are recommended to contact testing centers in advance for appointments and not expect to be able to test and receive PCR results the day of travel.  Test results may be delivered by e-mail or in hard copy provided in person; consult with the testing facility regarding the method results are communicated for your specific circumstance.  The Greek National Tourism Organization has published a list of diagnostic testing sites to take a PCR or Antigen (rapid) test via the GreeceHealthFirst.gr website.  They have also included a map of COVID-19 diagnostic testing locations in the Visit Greece app, which is available for download via Google Play or the App Store.  The U.S. Embassy does not endorse any particular diagnostic testing sites, and recommends that travelers contact sites in advance to make appointments and confirm necessary details.  For information on limited humanitarian exemptions to the COVID-19 testing requirement for U.S. entry, please review the following page: https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/traveladvisories/ea/covid-testing-required-us-entry.html.  If you review the information at the preceding link and believe you qualify for a humanitarian exemption despite widespread availability of testing in Greece, use the contact information at the bottom of this page to make your request.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220320124858/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Guidelines for primary schools, day care institutions and recreational activities:  -In the case of infection at schools and institutions etc., it will most often be other contacts that are of concern.  -Children, who are other contacts to an infected person (child or employee) in a day-care nursery etc., in school (including boarding schools and private schools) or in connection with recreational activities, must follow the recommendations for other contacts. Learn more in the section If you are an other contact.  -However, roommates at boarding schools etc., must follow the guidelines for close contacts.  https://archive.ph/PzGwC

Conditions for entry into Greenland:  -There is no longer a requirement to present a negative PCR test upon entry into Greenland.  -To be permitted to enter Greenland, you must either be fully vaccinated, a resident in Greenland or relocating to Greenland.  -You are considered fully vaccinated 14 days after you have completed a full vaccination programme, e.g. two doses of Pfizer or Moderna or one dose of Johnson&Johnson. There is currently no upper limit as to how long a person is considered fully vaccinated. There is no requirement for a booster vaccine to be considered fully vaccinated.    When you intend to travel to Greenland, you must remember to do the following:  -If you are not a resident in Greenland, you must bring documentation that you are fully vaccinated.  -If you are a resident in Greenland, you must bring a certificate of residence or something else that documents your residency  -If you are about to move to Greenland, you must show a lease, employment contract or something else that documents your move  Last updated Tuesday 22. february  https://web.archive.org/web/20220228044153/https://corona.nun.gl/en/travel/conditions-for-entry-into-greenland/

Conditions for entry into Greenland:  -There is no longer a requirement to present a negative PCR test upon entry into Greenland.  -To be permitted to enter Greenland, you must either be fully vaccinated, a resident in Greenland or relocating to Greenland.  -You are considered fully vaccinated 14 days after you have completed a full vaccination programme, e.g. two doses of Pfizer or Moderna or one dose of Johnson&Johnson. There is currently no upper limit as to how long a person is considered fully vaccinated. There is no requirement for a booster vaccine to be considered fully vaccinated.    When you intend to travel to Greenland, you must remember to do the following:  -If you are not a resident in Greenland, you must bring documentation that you are fully vaccinated.  -If you are a resident in Greenland, you must bring a certificate of residence or something else that documents your residency  -If you are about to move to Greenland, you must show a lease, employment contract or something else that documents your move  Last updated Tuesday 22. february  https://web.archive.org/web/20220228044153/https://corona.nun.gl/en/travel/conditions-for-entry-into-greenland/

Conditions for entry into Greenland:  -To be permitted to enter Greenland, you must either be fully vaccinated, a resident in Greenland or relocating to Greenland.  -There is no longer a requirement to present a negative PCR test upon entry into Greenland.    Requirements to enter Greenland by air or sea:  People who are 12 years old or older must be able to document one of the following things in order to enter Greenland by air or sea:  -If you are a resident in Greenland, you must document this with a certificate of residence or something else that documents your residency. You can download your certificate of residence at sullissivik.gl.  -If you are about to move to Greenland, you must be able to document that you have a job or a home in Greenland. For example, you can use a rental contract, a contract of employment or a letter from your coming employer as proof.  -If you are not a resident of Greenland you must be fully vaccinated against COVID-19 and able to provide documentation proving this.  -You are considered fully vaccinated 14 days after you have completed a full vaccination programme, e.g. two doses of Pfizer or Moderna or one dose of Johnson&Johnson. There is currently no upper limit as to how long a person is considered fully vaccinated. There is no requirement for a booster vaccination to be considered fully vaccinated. Only vaccines approved by EMA are accepted.  -Furthermore, you must live up to the rules on use of face masks during travel to Greenland.  Last updated Wednesday 2. march  https://archive.ph/dDMhY

Only vaccines approved by EMA are accepted.  -Furthermore, you must live up to the rules on use of face masks during travel to Greenland.  Last updated Wednesday 2. march  https://archive.ph/dDMhY

If you test positive:  Test result  -If your test result is positive, it means you are infected with the coronavirus.  -If your result from a PCR-test is positive, you will receive your test result via SMS. You are responsible for contacting your close contacts. Read more about the definition of a close contact.  -If you have taken an antigen test (home test) which shows a positive result, you should consider yourself infected with COVID-19. You must follow the same guidelines, but you will not be contacted by the health department / corona secretariat.  https://archive.ph/tPCET

Domestic travel in Greenland:  Face masks  -It is not a requirement to wear a face mask on Air Greenland domestic flights in Greenland. However, the authorities recommend that all domestic travellers over the age of 12 wear a face mask or visor that covers both nose and mouth.  Last updated Wednesday 16. february  https://archive.ph/0fqpG    Use of face masks and visors:  -Face masks can be used as a supplement for preventing the spread of infection in situations where it is difficult to keep to distance. It is important that you continue to follow the advice relating to keeping a distance and good hygiene even when you wear a face mask.    In Greenland, you must wear a face mask in the following situations:  -All individuals aged 12 years or older on international flights (face masks must be worn to the quarantine location/end destination).  If you have been infected or risk of being infected with COVID-19 and in exceptional circumstances must move outside, e.g. because you need to get tested.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220222044950/https://corona.nun.gl/en/prevention/use-of-face-masks-and-visors/

Good advice for people at a higher risk:  -In general, if you are someone who is at a higher risk, you can continue to do the things you did before the COVID-19 pandemic, e.g. go to work, participate in leisure activities and take care of your grandchildren.  -If before the COVID-19 pandemic, you had to follow special precautions in your daily life to avoid being infected with an infectious disease, e.g. you have a special condition and are immunocompromised, you should continue to follow those precautions.    The National Board of Health in Greenland (âLandslÃ¦geembedetâ) recommends the following for persons who are at a higher risk:  -Get re-vaccinated  -Follow the recommendations from the Office of the Medical Director of Health and ask others to be mindful  -Avoid large events and gatherings of people where you canât keep a distance to other people  -Consider using a face mask in public spaces where you canât keep a distance to other people  -Consider talking with your workplace about how to ensure that you can go to work safely    The older you are â the more and more serious chronic diseases have â the more attention you need to pay to following the recommendations. You must naturally take your quality of life into consideration, when you place limits on your life.  *Risk groups and highly vulnerable people  https://web.archive.org/web/20220215030314/https://corona.nun.gl/en/information-about-covid-19/

Self-testing on SARS-CoV-2 rapid antigen tests is voluntary and free and is performed once a week. Although it is recommended that students self-test on Mondays before school (or Sundays before bedtime), testing can be done on another day of the school-specific week, depending on when the first test is delivered to each school. It is important that the self-test is performed once a week and that the interval between the two tests is equal. For example, parents / guardians may record a negative test result in a student's notebook presented by the student at school or may report it in another way determined by the school.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220219124852/https://www.koronavirus.hr/upute-ravnateljima-o-primjeni-modela-ukidanja-samoizolacija-u-osnovnim-i-srednjim-skolama-uz-provodenje-redovitog-dobrovoljnog-samotestiranja-ucenika/1004

Restrictions for Individuals and Businesses  Businesses and individuals may be restricted due to the epidemiological measures based on your location in Croatia.    As of January 10, 2022, the Government of Croatia is imposing a range of epidemiological measures:    Indoor public gatherings are limited to 100 people. No limitation if everyone attending has a digital COVID-19 certificate.  Outdoor public gatherings are limited to no more than 200 people. No limitation if everyone attending has a digital COVID-19 certificate.  Catering/Dining/Bars are permitted to be open until 2 AM.  Individual counties and cities may have additional measures. Please visit?the?Croatian Governmentâs COVID-19 website?for additional information.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220321234433/https://hr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Transportation Options:  Are commercial flights operating? Yes  Is public transportation operating? Yes  Wearing protective masks is mandatory?throughout?the country?in public transportation.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220321234433/https://hr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No change in policy.  The necessary epidemiological measure of self-isolation is automatically determined for all passengers in transit, including personnel in the transport sector, if they do not leave the Republic of Croatia within 12 hours from the moment of entering the Republic of Croatia.    Citizens of EU Member States (including Croatian citizens), i.e. Schengen Member States and Schengen associated countries, as well as members of their families and third-country nationals who are long-term residents under Council Directive 2003/109/EC of 25 November 2003 concerning the status of third-country nationals who are long-term residents and persons entitled to reside under other EU directives or national law or who have national long-term visas and are coming from third countries, must present a valid EU Digital COVID Certificate when entering the Republic of Croatia.    Exceptionally, the abovementioned category of passengers who do not yet possess an EU Digital COVID Certificate will be allowed entry into the Republic of Croatia if they have the following:     negative PCR test result or rapid antigen test result - RAT for SARS-CoV-2, where the RAT test must be listed in the Common list of rapid antigen tests recognized by the Member States of the European Union, published by the European Commission. If the RAT test results were made abroad, the manufacturer and/or the commercial name of the test must be visible. Otherwise, it will not be accepted as credible for entering the Republic of Croatia.  The PCR test result must not be older than 72 hours and the RAT test result must not be older than 24 hours, counting from the time the test was taken until the arrival at the border crossing point;   certificate that they have received two doses of vaccine used in the EU Member States (Pfizer, Moderna, AstaZeneca, Gamaleya, Sinopharm, Novavax) or vaccines approved by the World Health Organization for emergency use (Serum Institute of India - Covishield, Bharat Biotech - Covaxin, Sinovac - CoronaVac) not older than 270 days, provided that 14 days have passed since receiving the second dose of the vaccine, or a certificate that they have received one dose of the vaccine if the vaccine is administered in a single dose (Janssen/Johnson&Johnson) not older than 270 days, provided that 14 days have passed since they received the single dose, or a certificate that they have received the booster dose of the vaccine;  certificate showing that they have recovered from COVID-19 and have received one dose of vaccine used in EU Member States (Pfizer, Moderna, AstaZeneca, Gamaleya, Sinopharm, Novavax, Janssen/Johnson&Johnson) or a vaccine approved by the World Health Organization for emergency use (Serum Institute of India - Covishield, Bharat Biotech - Covaxin, Sinovac - CoronaVac), provided that 14 days have passed since they received the single dose within eight months from contracting the disease, provided that the vaccine was administered less than 270 days from their arrival at the border crossing point;  positive PCR test result or rapid antigen test result, confirming that the holder recovered from the SARS-CoV-2 virus infection, which was performed in the previous 180 days and which is older than 11 days from the date of arrival at the border crossing point, or  a medical certificate of recovery;  or if they perform PCR testing or rapid antigen testing - RAT for SARS-CoV-2 immediately upon their arrival in the Republic of Croatia (at their own expense), with the obligation to stay in self-isolation until they obtain a negative test result. In case they cannot get tested, they have to self-isolate for seven (7) days.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220219130513/https://mup.gov.hr/uzg-covid/english/286212

English  This site contains information regarding the conditions of entry into the Republic of Croatia considering temporary bans, i.e. restrictions in place to prevent the spread of COVID-19.    If you cannot find the answer to your question, please contact us by filling in the form below.    Note: The necessary epidemiological measure of self-isolation is automatically determined for all passengers in transit, including personnel in the transport sector, if they do not leave the Republic of Croatia within 12 hours from the moment of entering the Republic of Croatia.     Passengers travelling to the Republic of Croatia from an EU / EEA member state    Passengers coming directly from the countries and/or regions of the European Union, i.e. countries and/or regions of the Schengen area and Schengen associated countries, regardless of their citizenship, will be allowed entry into the Republic of Croatia if they possess a valid EU Digital COVID Certificate.    Exceptionally, passengers arriving directly from the countries and/or regions of the European Union, i.e. countries and/or regions of the Schengen area and Schengen associated countries, who do not yet possess an EU Digital COVID Certificate, will be allowed entry into the Republic of Croatia if they have the following:     negative PCR test result or rapid antigen test result - RAT for SARS-CoV-2, where the RAT test must be listed in the Common list of rapid antigen tests recognized by the Member States of the European Union, published by the European Commission. If the RAT test results were made abroad, the manufacturer and/or the commercial name of the test must be visible. Otherwise, it will not be accepted as credible for entering the Republic of Croatia.  The PCR test result must not be older than 72 hours and the RAT test result must not be older than 24 hours, counting from the time the test was taken until the arrival at the border crossing point;   certificate that they have received two doses of vaccine used in the EU Member States (Pfizer, Moderna, AstaZeneca, Gamaleya, Sinopharm, Novavax) or vaccines approved by the World Health Organization for emergency use (Serum Institute of India - Covishield, Bharat Biotech - Covaxin, Sinovac - CoronaVac) not older than 270 days, provided that 14 days have passed since receiving the second dose of the vaccine, or a certificate that they have received one dose of the vaccine if the vaccine is administered in a single dose (Janssen/Johnson&Johnson) not older than 270 days, provided that 14 days have passed since they received the single dose, or a certificate that they have received the booster dose of the vaccine;  certificate showing that they have recovered from COVID-19 and have received one dose of vaccine used in EU Member States (Pfizer, Moderna, AstaZeneca, Gamaleya, Sinopharm, Novavax, Janssen/Johnson&Johnson) or a vaccine approved by the World Health Organization for emergency use (Serum Institute of India - Covishield, Bharat Biotech - Covaxin, Sinovac - CoronaVac), provided that 14 days have passed since they received the single dose within eight months from contracting the disease, provided that the vaccine was administered less than 270 days from their arrival at the border crossing point;   positive PCR test result or rapid antigen test result, confirming that the holder recovered from the SARS-CoV-2 virus infection, which was performed in the previous 180 days and which is older than 11 days from the date of arrival at the border crossing point, or  a medical certificate of recovery;  or if they perform PCR testing or rapid antigen testing - RAT for SARS-CoV-2 immediately upon their arrival in the Republic of Croatia (at their own expense), with the obligation to stay in self-isolation until they obtain a negative test result. In case they cannot get tested, they have to self-isolate for seven (7) days.    The following categories are exempt from possessing a valid EU Digital COVID Certificate or from the abovementioned obligations:     workers or self-employed persons performing essential tasks, including healthcare workers, frontier and posted workers and seasonal workers as specified in the Guidelines concerning  the exercise of the free movement of workers during COVID-19 outbreak;  pupils, students and interns  seafarers and workers in the transport sector or transport service providers, including heavy goods vehicle drivers transporting goods to be used in the national territory and those in transit only;  diplomats, staff of international organizations and persons invited by international organizations and whose physical presence is necessary for the functioning of those organizations, military personnel and police officers, as well as humanitarian and civil protection personnel in the performance of their duties;  persons traveling for family or business reasons, including journalists in the performance of their duties;  passengers in transit with the obligation to leave the Republic of Croatia within 12 hours from entry;  patients traveling for health reasons.    The provisions regarding frontier workers apply adequately to other categories of passengers who, due to the nature of their job or occupation, need to cross the state border frequently (e.g. athletes playing for clubs in a neighbouring country).    Passengers who represent one of the previously mentioned exceptions are obliged to present credible documentation upon entering the Republic of Croatia in order to prove the reasons for the exemption.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220321235048/https://mup.gov.hr/uzg-covid/english/286212

COVID-19 Vaccine Information:  Has the government of Croatia approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use? Yes  Are vaccines available in Croatia for U.S. citizens to receive? Yes  Which vaccines are available in Croatia? PfizerâBioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca and Johnson & Johnson.  According to the Croatian Institute for Public Health, foreigners with temporary or permanent residency in Croatia can register for the COVID-19 vaccine through their local healthcare provider.  If you have an OIB (Croatian Personal Identification Number) and a local health insurance plan, you may visit https://cijepise.zdravlje.hr/ to register to get vaccinated.  If you do not have a local health insurance plan, you may visit the following Croatian Institute of Public Health website for the contact details of the county public health institutes to register by phone.  Visit the FDAâs website to?learn more about FDA-approved vaccines?in the United States.  The United States Government does not plan to provide COVID-19 vaccinations to private U.S. citizens overseas. Please follow host country developments and guidelines for COVID-19 vaccination.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220321234433/https://hr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No evidence to suggest that policy has changed since the 28th of February. Therefore, schools are likely fully open.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228190945/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse

Employers are allowed to require their employees to be vaccinated, either as a standard working condition for all workers or as an individual working condition, depending on the job. For workers who have not yet been vaccinated, the employer may set a deadline of 45 days for taking the first vaccination. Vaccination is expected in the public sector, and mayors can decide on it.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228192100/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis

Vaccine passes are no longer required for employees.   Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220324212653/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis  https://web.archive.org/web/20220324213215/https://www.traveloffpath.com/hungary-becomes-the-9th-country-to-remove-all-entry-requirements/

All indoor events and outdoor events with more than 500 people attending require an immunity certificate. This certificate is provided to all those who have received their first vaccine dose). It is valid for six months after the second vaccination, after which it will only be extended is the third booster dose has been given. After the third booster dose, the certificate will be valid indefinitely.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228192100/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis & http://web.archive.org/web/20220228191612/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/hungary/coronavirus

Vaccine passes are no longer required to attend events.  Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220324212653/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis  https://web.archive.org/web/20220324213215/https://www.traveloffpath.com/hungary-becomes-the-9th-country-to-remove-all-entry-requirements/

All indoor events and outdoor events with more than 500 people attending require an immunity certificate. This certificate is provided to all those who have received their first vaccine dose). It is valid for six months after the second vaccination, after which it will only be extended is the third booster dose has been given. After the third booster dose, the certificate will be valid indefinitely.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228192100/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis & http://web.archive.org/web/20220228191612/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/hungary/coronavirus

Vaccine passes are no longer required to attend events.  Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220324212653/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis  https://web.archive.org/web/20220324213215/https://www.traveloffpath.com/hungary-becomes-the-9th-country-to-remove-all-entry-requirements/

Masks are required on all public transport, and proof of immunity is also required on some means of public transport.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228193937/https://wiki.unece.org/display/CTRBSBC/Hungary & http://web.archive.org/web/20220228192100/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis

Masks are no longer mandatory on public transport, but are recommended.  Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220324212653/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis  https://web.archive.org/web/20220324213215/https://www.traveloffpath.com/hungary-becomes-the-9th-country-to-remove-all-entry-requirements/

There is no curfew. People who suspect they have the virus are asked to stay at home and avoid going out into the community.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228192100/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis

There is no curfew. People who suspect they have the virus are asked to stay at home and avoid going out into the community.  Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220324212653/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis

No restrictions on internal movement. Whilst proof of immunity is required on some means of public transport, there is no physical restriction on unvaccinated people moving within Hungary.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228193937/https://wiki.unece.org/display/CTRBSBC/Hungary & http://web.archive.org/web/20220228192100/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis
No restrictions on internal movement.  Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220324212653/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis

People entering Hungary must agree to enter mandatory quarantine unless one of the following applies:  - You are in possession a Hungary issued Immunity Certificate, EU Covid certificate, or obtain UK proof of vaccination (final dose must have been administered at least 14 days prior to travel)  - You have a negative PCR test from the past 72 hours  - You are arriving by road, rail and waterway from one of Hungaryâs neighbouring countries,  - You meet one of the exemptions for vaccination  It is possible to leave quarantine early following two negative COVID-19 tests within 5 days of each other but at least 48 hours apart.  Unless you are a Hungarian national, or arriving on land from a neighbouring country, people entering Hungary will be subject to a temperature check on arrival.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228194631/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/hungary/entry-requirements

Vaccine passes are no longer required for entry into Hungary.  Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220324212653/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis  https://web.archive.org/web/20220324213215/https://www.traveloffpath.com/hungary-becomes-the-9th-country-to-remove-all-entry-requirements/

Several measures are in place:  - parents receive a family tax refund. In February 2022, parents raising a child will be refunded their income tax paid in 2021 up to the average wage tax level.  - Retirees received a larger-than-ever pension premium of HUF 80,000 in November and will receive a full refund  of their 13-month pension in February 2022 .  - Wage increases will continue: from January 2022, the minimum wage will be HUF 200,000 and the guaranteed minimum wage will be HUF 260,000,  thus the minimum wage will be higher from 2022 onwards.  - Young people under the age of  25 will not have to pay income tax from January 2022.  Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220324212653/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis

The credit moratorium was extended until June 30, 2022. Those who are expecting and raising a child, retirees, public employees can continue to take advantage of the opportunity, as can businesses and individuals whose incomes have fallen significantly from the previous year.  Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20220324212653/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis
Up to date information is available via a publicly available website.  Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20220324212653/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis

Anyone suspected of having COVID-19 can order a test through their GP or a hospital for free. Outside of this, the officially regulated price for a PCR test is 19,500 HUF, with antigen tests being offered from 8,500 to 15,000 HUF. Some facilities offer express results for an additional fee.  Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20220324215446/https://hu.usembassy.gov/covid-19/

A contract tracing app (VirusRadar) was launched in May 2020, but there is no evidence of its broad or consistent use.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228195241/https://nextsense.com/ns-newsarticle-virusradar-a-mobile-contact-tracing-implemented.nspx

Masks are required in most indoor spaces, including inside retail establishments, hotels, restaurants, theaters, cinemas, government buildings, medical facilities, and on public transport. They are not required outdoors.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228191128/https://hu.usembassy.gov/covid-19/ & http://web.archive.org/web/20220228192100/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis

Masks are no longer mandatory on public transport, but are recommended.  Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220324212653/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis  https://web.archive.org/web/20220324213215/https://www.traveloffpath.com/hungary-becomes-the-9th-country-to-remove-all-entry-requirements/

Vaccines are generally available, with Pfizer, Moderna, Astra Zeneca, Sinopharm, Sputnik V all being used. Vaccination is now allowed for children over 5 years of age.  Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220324212653/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis

Visits to hospitals are not allowed. Visits to social care facilities are allowed, but it is mandatory to wear face masks.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228191612/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/hungary/coronavirus

The Government has approved plans to remove almost all Covid-19 related restrictions next Monday (28th Feb)    In schools and childcare pods for children, staggered breaks and physical distancing can also end from Monday. These settings will still be required to practice good hygiene and have good ventilation, while children should stay at home if they are sick.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220226075802/https://www.irishtimes.com/news/health/cabinet-agrees-to-drop-almost-all-remaining-covid-19-rules-from-monday-1.4808912

on 28 Feb, all restrictions in Ireland ended, and only guidance applies now.     Protect yourself and others from COVID-19    If you have any symptoms of COVID-19, even mild ones, you should:    - self-isolate (stay in your room) until 48 hours after your symptoms are mostly or fully gone  - wear a face mask if you have to be around other people    Do these even if you completed your first round of COVID-19 vaccination, had a booster, or had COVID-19 in the past.    Do    - get a COVID-19 vaccine and booster dose when it's available to you    - keep at least 2 metres (around 6 feet) away from people you do not live with    - wash your hands properly and often    - wear a face mask in crowded places outdoors and when you move around in public indoor spaces    - cover coughs or sneezes with a tissue or your sleeve - put used tissues into a bin and wash your hands    - meet people outdoors where possible    - try to avoid crowded places where you cannot keep a distance from people - there's a greater risk of infection in crowded and enclosed places    - check that visitors to your home or workplace do not have symptoms of COVID-19, colds or flu    - let fresh air into your home by opening windows, doors and air vents as much as possible when you have visitors    - clean objects and surfaces that other people touch      Don't    - do not touch your eyes, nose or mouth if your hands are not clean    - do not share objects that touch your mouth, for example, bottles or cups    - do not shake hands or make close contact with other people, if possible    - do not wear gloves instead of washing your hands - your hands can get contaminated when you take them off      https://web.archive.org/web/20220319141023/https://www2.hse.ie/conditions/covid19/preventing-the-spread/protect-yourself-and-others/

Since 1 February 2022, a standard acceptance period of 14 days after the final dose in a primary vaccine series of a vaccine will be required for all vaccines accepted for travel to Ireland.    You are fully vaccinated when it is:    14 days after the second AstraZeneca dose or second Covishield dose  14 days after the second Pfizer-BioNtech dose  14 days after the second Moderna dose  14 days after the single Janssen dose  14 days after the second Sinopharm dose (also called Vero Cell Inactivated)  14 days after your second dose of Coronavac (Sinovac)  14 days after your second dose of Covaxin  14 days after your second dose of of Novavax (Nuvaxovid)    https://web.archive.org/web/20220222092310/https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/travel_and_recreation/travel_to_ireland/travel_to_ireland_during_covid.htmla

From 6 March 2022, all COVID-19 travel restrictions are removed. You no longer need to complete a passenger locator form. You also no longer need proof of vaccination or recovery, or a COVID-19 test.    You should follow public health advice if you develop symptoms of COVID-19 or if you are a close contact of a confirmed case of COVID-19.      https://web.archive.org/web/20220308070549/https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/travel_and_recreation/travel_to_ireland/travel_to_ireland_during_covid.html

By law, you must wear a face covering when using public transport. This includes in taxis, as well as in bus and rail stations.    Mask wearing will still be required in the following settings:    public transport, taxis and at stations/airports/ports  retail premises (including shopping centres, libraries, cinemas, theatres, museums, post offices, banks, credit unions), public offices and at premises providing specified services and businesses (incl. salons, hairdressers, travel agents, laundries, dry cleaners, bookmakers)  workers in customer facing and food preparation roles in premises where food and beverages are sold for consumption on the premises  healthcare settings    https://web.archive.org/web/20220222092940/https://www.gov.ie/en/press-release/0fc0d-government-announces-that-most-of-the-public-health-measures-currently-in-place-can-be-removed/?referrer=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.gov.ie%2Fen%2Fpublication%2F3361b-public-health-updates%2F      From 28 February 2022, it is no longer mandatory to wear a face covering on public transport, in taxis, shops, schools and other indoor public areas. Staff in hospitality settings will no longer need to wear a face covering. . You are still recommended to wear a face mask in hospitals and health settings.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220222091958/https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/health/covid19/face_coverings_during_covid19.html

The Government has approved plans to remove almost all Covid-19 related restrictions next Monday (28th Feb)    Under a plan that went to Cabinet, all legal requirements to wear masks will expire after February 28th, with their use only required in healthcare settings. People will be advised to exercise their own judgement on the use of masks in schools, in retail settings and on public transport.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220226075802/https://www.irishtimes.com/news/health/cabinet-agrees-to-drop-almost-all-remaining-covid-19-rules-from-monday-1.4808912

28/02/22    Face masks  Face masks must be worn wherever the 1 meter social distancing rule cannot be observed between people who are unrelated.    Mask obligation does not apply to children born 2006 or later.    Face masks must be used where it is not possible to ensure 1 meter of social distancing, such as in healthcare services, museums, domestic flights and ferries, public transport, taxis and coaches, in practical driving lessons and flight training, hairdressers, beauty salons, massage parlours, tattoo parlours, dog grooming salons, tanning salons and other similar activities. Face mask needs to cover both nose and mouth.    Those who do not have the understanding or maturity to use a face mask correctly or are unable to do so for other reasons, such as health reasons, do not have to wear a mask.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220221212536/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/effective-restrictions

28/02/22    Effective restrictions on gatherings  As of Friday 25 February 2022 all public restrictions due to the COVID-19 pandemic will be lifted, both domestically and at the border.  Limits to the number of people at gatherings are none  Social distancing rules are none  Masks are not mandatory anywhere  Restrictions on any kind of operations are no longer applicable, neither the obligation to register guests nor restrictions on opening hours  Personal infection preventative measures are encouraged and if we experience symptoms we get tested.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220228210608/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/effective-restrictions

no changes in policy.   Green passes are still required only for university students: for university students that are non-vaccinated, there is a requirement to show a negative-test or a certification that they recently recovered from Covid. For unvaccinated university students school is otherwise closed.  For vaccinated students masks and social distancing (desks/seats 1m apart) are still required.    Starting Dec 6th a vaccine mandate is in place for all school personnel.   University students still need to hold a green pass to attend lessons in presence.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220112055726/https://www.mur.gov.it/it/news/sabato-08012022/obbligo-vaccinale-il-personale-di-universita-e-afam-dal-1deg-febbraio

The number of orange zones is stable, in such zones curfews are in place except for the vaccinated and recently recovered from Covid (Super Green Pass).  Social distancing and masks are mandatory almost anywhere for everyone, including the vaccinated.  For regions that are classified as Yellow zones no curfews are in place.  Some Italian regions are still classified as white zones.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220128174715/https://www.ilgiorno.it/cronaca/super-green-pass-zone-1.7077178  https://web.archive.org/web/20220220154020/https://www.qualitytravel.it/colori-regioni-covid-19-le-nuove-zone-rosse-arancioni-gialle-e-bianche-dal-22-marzo/92843    A new summary table has been created to clearly explain which activities are possible in every zone with or without a Green Pass (negative test, vaccinated or fully recovered) or a Super Green Pass (only vaccinated or fully recovered from Covid):   https://web.archive.org/web/20220216132158/https://www.governo.it/sites/governo.it/files/documenti/documenti/Notizie-allegati/tabella_attivita_consentite.pdf

The number of orange zones is decreasing, only Friuli is now classified as Orange. In such zones curfews are in place except for the vaccinated and recently recovered from Covid (Super Green Pass). For most countries, except for European countries, it is mandatory to exhibit a negative test (antigen or PCR) in conjunction with a Super Green Pass (vaccinated or recovered), if this is not done people will only be admitted if they have residency or working permits, and will therefore have to self-quarantine. For tourism and without a proof of vaccination, it won't be possible to enter Italy from countries in the D & E list.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220219173252/https://www.salute.gov.it/portale/nuovocoronavirus/dettaglioContenutiNuovoCoronavirus.jsp?lingua=italiano&id=5411&area=nuovoCoronavirus&menu=vuoto

For most countries, except for European countries, it is mandatory to exhibit a negative test (antigen or PCR) in conjunction with a Super Green Pass (vaccinated or recovered), if this is not done people will only be admitted if they have residency or working permits, and will therefore have to self-quarantine. For tourism and without a proof of vaccination, it won't be possible to enter Italy from countries in the D & E list.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220219173252/https://www.salute.gov.it/portale/nuovocoronavirus/dettaglioContenutiNuovoCoronavirus.jsp?lingua=italiano&id=5411&area=nuovoCoronavirus&menu=vuoto

From March 1st almost all restrictions have been removed. The only restrictions still in place are to show a "green pass equivalent" certificate (so not a vaccine mandate).  Vaccinated people therefore just need to show their vaccination status, unvaccinated people need to show a negative test or proof or recent recovery from Covid. In case a proof of vaccination or recent recovery cannot be provided they will need to quarantine.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220303173230/https://www.salute.gov.it/portale/nuovocoronavirus/dettaglioContenutiNuovoCoronavirus.jsp?lingua=italiano&id=5411&area=nuovoCoronavirus&menu=vuoto  https://web.archive.org/web/20220301212105/https://www.ilsole24ore.com/art/da-oggi-piu-facile-viaggiare-stop-quarantena-e-green-pass-base-chi-entra-italia-paesi-extra-ue-AEx0F3GB

From March 1st almost all travel restrictions have been removed. The only restrictions still in place are to show a "green pass equivalent" certificate (so not a vaccine mandate).  Vaccinated people therefore just need to show their vaccination status, unvaccinated people need to show a negative test or proof or recent recovery from Covid. In case a proof of vaccination or recent recovery cannot be provided they will need to quarantine.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220303173230/https://www.salute.gov.it/portale/nuovocoronavirus/dettaglioContenutiNuovoCoronavirus.jsp?lingua=italiano&id=5411&area=nuovoCoronavirus&menu=vuoto  https://web.archive.org/web/20220301212105/https://www.ilsole24ore.com/art/da-oggi-piu-facile-viaggiare-stop-quarantena-e-green-pass-base-chi-entra-italia-paesi-extra-ue-AEx0F3GB

From Feb 11th masks are not required outside when social distancing can be guaranteed.  The Campania region though still enforces masks everywhere.  Mask mandates are irrespective of vaccination status throughout Italy.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220216144835/https://www.quotidiano.net/napoli/covid-campania-oggi-15-febbraio-1.7367334  https://web.archive.org/web/20220211063744/https://www.corriere.it/cronache/22_febbraio_08/mascherine-aperto-11-febbraio-c619385e-8859-11ec-8804-7df4f9fb61d8.shtml

From Feb 11th masks are not required outside when social distancing can be guaranteed.  The Campania region though still enforces masks everywhere until end of February.  Mask mandates are irrespective of vaccination status throughout Italy.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220216144835/https://www.quotidiano.net/napoli/covid-campania-oggi-15-febbraio-1.7367334  https://web.archive.org/web/20220211063744/https://www.corriere.it/cronache/22_febbraio_08/mascherine-aperto-11-febbraio-c619385e-8859-11ec-8804-7df4f9fb61d8.shtml

Vaccine mandates are in place for:  - all school & university personnel (including teachers)  - everyone 50+ (from Jan 8th) - see this link where no mention is made to the fact that the mandate is only for workers, implying that it applies to everyone https://web.archive.org/web/20220201230058/https://www.salute.gov.it/portale/news/p3_2_1_1_1.jsp?lingua=italiano&menu=notizie&p=dalministero&id=5754  - healthcare workers (everyone working in healthcare facilities, that is: not limited to nurses and doctors)  - long term care facilities personnel    The mandate is **NOT** in place for taxi drivers, security guards or government officials. Vaccine mandates are in place for:  - all school & university personnel (including teachers)  - everyone 50+ (from Jan 8th)  - healthcare workers (everyone working in healthcare facilities, so this is not limited to nurses and doctors)  - long term care facilities personnel  - law enforcement and public rescue personnel, jail guards and public cybersecurity personnel (as they are still military personnel)    It is clearly stated at the following link that the vaccine mandate is for everyone 50+, not just workers. At the same link, you can find a detailed list of the categories for which a mandate is in place: https://web.archive.org/web/20220311173308/https://www.salute.gov.it/portale/nuovocoronavirus/dettaglioContenutiNuovoCoronavirus.jsp?lingua=italiano&id=5452&area=nuovoCoronavirus&menu=vuoto    The mandate is **NOT** in place for taxi drivers, private security guards or government officials. 22/3/22  Domestic Measures  Domestic inter-regional transport services, including flights between Bishkek and Osh, are operating, though may have reduced services. Passengers may need to undergo health screenings before boarding. Most businesses are operating subject to social distancing requirements.    Authorities continue to advise against nonessential travel, and all persons leaving their accommodations must carry a contact-tracing form. Public gatherings are prohibited. Facemasks are mandatory on public transport and on some business premises.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220322100315/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/03/kyrgyzstan-authorities-maintaining-covid-19-related-measures-as-of-march-17-update-28

* Is public transportation operating? Yes      * Bishkek city public transport operates on weekdays and weekends from 7:00 â 23:00.      * Masks are required on public transit.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220318201056/https://kg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220318200710/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/01/kyrgyzstan-covid-19-related-restrictions-in-effect-as-of-jan-4-remain-largely-unchanged-compared-with-early-december-update-26
No changes found.
* Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? NoÂ   https://web.archive.org/web/20220318201056/https://kg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

* As of February 11, 2021, travelers may show their original vaccine card showing proof of vaccination against COVID-19 instead of a negative PCR test. Non-vaccinated travelers must provide a negative PCR test.  PCR tests must be taken no more than 72 hours before arrival into Kyrgyzstan.  If your PCR test expires en route due to flight delays or cancellations, you will be required to test again upon arrival at your own expense.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220318201056/https://kg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No policy change.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20220318201400/https://covid19policy.adb.org/policy-measures/KGZ
No policy change.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20220318201400/https://covid19policy.adb.org/policy-measures/KGZ

The Ministry of Health provides free testing only for symptomatic patients. For those requiring a negative PCR test for travel, state laboratories in Bishkek and Osh can provide tests for a fee (approximately $20), depending on testing capacity. Private COVID-19 testing is also available for a fee ($30) at Bonetsky Laboratory or Aqualab.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220318201056/https://kg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

All travellers leaving their accommodations must carry a contact-tracing form, and there is a QR code system in place, but there is was no evidence found to show that all COVID-19 cases are being traced.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220318200710/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/01/kyrgyzstan-covid-19-related-restrictions-in-effect-as-of-jan-4-remain-largely-unchanged-compared-with-early-december-update-26

As of the 16th of February 2022, private and public events can be held and attended without Corona protection measures in place or COVID certificates required. There are no restrictions on private gatherings, though public gatherings with audience still have a cap of 1000 people.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220305133605/https://tourismus.li/en/our-country/about-liechtenstein/current-information-on-covid-19-in-the-principality-of-liechtenstein/ & http://web.archive.org/web/20220305140637/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/liechtenstein/coronavirus

Public transport is operating. All over the age of 12 are required to wear a mask in trains, trams, and buses, as well as on mountain rail and cableways and on lake and river boats.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220305140405/https://ch.usembassy.gov/covid-19-info/

Public transport is fully open.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220319221552/https://tourismus.li/en/our-country/about-liechtenstein/current-information-on-covid-19-in-the-principality-of-liechtenstein/

There are no recommendations or requirements to stay at home; people who test positive must still isolate for a period of at least 5 days.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220305135408/https://www.regierung.li/coronavirus

Stay at home requirements and recommendations have been lifted.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220319221552/https://tourismus.li/en/our-country/about-liechtenstein/current-information-on-covid-19-in-the-principality-of-liechtenstein/
There are no restrictions in place.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220305140405/https://ch.usembassy.gov/covid-19-info/

There are no restrictions on internal movement.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220319221552/https://tourismus.li/en/our-country/about-liechtenstein/current-information-on-covid-19-in-the-principality-of-liechtenstein/

The same rules for entering Switzerland apply to entering Liechtenstein. You may only enter if you are fully vaccinated, with the final vaccine dose having been delivered in the past 270 days; if you are fully vaccinated, no negative test or entry form is required. If you are not fully vaccinated, and are not an EU, Swiss, or Liechtenstein national, or holder of a residency permit, you may not enter the country.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220305134613/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/de/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/empfehlungen-fuer-reisende/quarantaene-einreisende.html & http://web.archive.org/web/20220305134849/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/liechtenstein/entry-requirements

It is possible to apply for and receive short-time work compensation due to the economic consequences of the pandemic. This is officially in place until the end of March 2022, with the possibility of extension until June 2022.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220305143517/https://www.serviceportal.li/de/medienmitteilungen/moeglichkeit-fuer-corona-bedingte-kurzarbeitsentschaedigung-soll-bis-juni-2022-verlaengert-werden & http://web.archive.org/web/20220305144018/https://www.admin.ch/gov/de/start/dokumentation/medienmitteilungen.msg-id-84116.html

The test centre in Vaduz in the Marktplatzgarage is open daily from 14:00 to 17:00. No appointment is necessary, and results are available within 24-36 hours. The test if free if you have health insurance, and you do not have to be symptomatic to order one.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220305133605/https://tourismus.li/en/our-country/about-liechtenstein/current-information-on-covid-19-in-the-principality-of-liechtenstein/ & http://web.archive.org/web/20220305135408/https://www.regierung.li/coronavirus

Residents aged 5 and over can register for vaccination, with booster vaccines available for all those 12 and over. The Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines are being used. Since the mandate for COVID Passport was lifted by the Lithuanian Government on Feb 05, the only current requirement is that a total of 15 sq.m per visitor per visitor trading venues located in enclosed space is applicable. Per the Ministry of Economy and Innovation for Lithuania, When an enterprise declares inactivity due to an emergency or quarantine the worker shall receive at least the minimum monthly salary and shall not be required to arrive to work.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220228181226/https://eimin.lrv.lt/en/important-information-for-business-on-coronavirus-3/important-information-for-business-on-coronavirus-2/important-information-for-business-on-coronavirus

Per the Ministry of Economy and Innovation, there is support for employee's salaries as well as subsidies if needed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220314160851/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/lt/covid-19-pandemijos-valdymo-priemones  https://web.archive.org/web/20220314161317/https://eimin.lrv.lt/en/important-information-for-business-on-coronavirus-1

Per the Ministry of Economy and Innovation for Lithuania, Emergency tax loans, with deferred taxes, including suspension of taxes and paying fines and interest on loans are deferred.  Also implemented programs to accelerate payments and fundings to business as well as addition date guarantees in order to create to supplement existing financial instruments.  Enabling municipalities to invest in projects.  The bank of Lithuania also increased lending limits and reduced capital requirements for credit.      https://web.archive.org/web/20220228181226/https://eimin.lrv.lt/en/important-information-for-business-on-coronavirus-3/important-information-for-business-on-coronavirus-2/important-information-for-business-on-coronavirus

Anyone over the age of 18 attending a public event must present either a negative PCR COVID-19 test (taken in the last 72 hours) or an antigen test (taken in the last 48 hours); a COVID-19 vaccine certificate; a medical certificate attesting the person had COVID-19 in the previous 6 months; or a COVID-19 antibodies certificate valid for 90 days from the exam date.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220228173150/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

PCR and antigen testing is available at both public and private medical laboratories. "On Friday 25 February we will take the final step. From then, opening times will return to normal and we will lift the following requirements: showing a coronavirus entry pass (3G) at locations accommodating fewer than 500 people, staying 1.5 metres apart, wearing face masks while walking around bars and restaurants, schools and shops, having a limited number of visitors, and assigned seating in bars, restaurants and other venues. That means that large night clubs, discotheques, festivals and events can open up without limitations. At indoor locations accommodating more than 500 people where there is no assigned seating, for example night clubs and festivals, everyone must show a negative test result. This does not apply at events where there is a continuous flow of visitors, such as trade fairs and conferences. To ensure that vulnerable people are able to travel safely, the requirement to wear a face mask on public transport and at airports will remain in force even after 25 February."  https://archive.fo/M1c8X#selection-163.0-166.0

25/2/22  All students have returend to school.    From February 21, 2022, all students returned to full-time education.     Detailed information is available on the website of the Ministry of Education and Science .    Find out more about general school rules.    Face masks are still required    https://web.archive.org/web/20220225131746/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/opieka-i-edukacja    The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / customer service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, clinic, hospital, massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  in schools and universities during breaks between lessons and classes, unless otherwise decided by the head of the entity.

Detailed information is available on the website of the Ministry of Education and Science .    Find out more about general school rules.    Face masks are still required    https://web.archive.org/web/20220225131746/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/opieka-i-edukacja    The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / customer service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, clinic, hospital, massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  in schools and universities during breaks between lessons and classes, unless otherwise decided by the head of the entity.

4/3/22  From 1st March Rules have been relaxed and masks are now required indoors only.    Covering the mouth and nose only with a mask  Covering the mouth and nose in confined spaces is mandatory throughout the country.  Only cover the nose and mouth with a mask. Scarves, visors and dishes are not allowed because they do not fulfill their primary function, i.e. they do not protect against the virus!    The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / customer service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, clinic, hospital, massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  in schools and universities during breaks between lessons and classes, unless otherwise decided by the head of the entity.  Where do you not need to cover your mouth and nose?    In the open air, in the forest, park, greenery, botanical gardens, historic gardens, on roads and squares, in cemeteries, promenades, boulevards, parking places for vehicles, forest parking lots, in family allotments and on the beach, and during private travel by car, motorcycle, quadricycle, moped, at the workplace to eat.     Detailed information on covering the mouth and nose as well as information on exceptions to this rule can be found in the regulation .    https://web.archive.org/web/20220304082256/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/dystans-spoleczny-i-maseczki

25/2/22  30& capacity limit for unvaccinated and masks required for everyone.    Attention! The number of persons vaccinated against COVID-19 is not counted if they show:    EU digital COVID certificate;  or a certificate of vaccination, test result and recovery.  If the indicated documents are not presented, the entrepreneur has the right to refuse to provide services.    Museums and art galleries  They function in a strict sanitary regime. There is a limit of people - 1 person. on 15 m2.    Cinemas  They operate in a strict sanitary regime - max. 30 percent. occupancy. It is necessary to cover the mouth and nose.    It is not allowed to eat or drink in the cinemas.    Theaters, operas, philharmonics  Outdoor:    They operate in a strict sanitary regime - max. 30 percent. occupancy. Maintain a distance of 1.5 m between viewers or listeners.    In rooms:    They operate in a strict sanitary regime - max. 30 percent. occupancy. Maintain a distance of 1.5 m between viewers or listeners. Ensuring that no more than 1 person per 15 m2 of the area is present in the room at the same time. It is necessary to cover the mouth and nose.    Houses and centers of culture  Conducting activities by cultural centers and centers as well as community centers is allowed in the open air and indoors, provided that the participation does not exceed 30%. participants. Ensure that participants follow the order to cover their mouth and nose.    Concerts and circus performances  Events may take place under the following conditions:    making available to viewers or listeners no more than 30 percent. number of seats,    keep a distance of 1.5 m between viewers or listeners in the absence of designated seats in the audience and ensure that no more than 1 person per 15 square meters is present in the room at the same time,    ensure that viewers or listeners comply with the order to cover their mouth and nose.    Concerts and circus performances may be organized outdoors under the following conditions:    making available to viewers or listeners no more than 30 percent. number of seats,    keep a distance of 1.5 m between viewers or listeners in the absence of designated seats in the audience,    ensure that viewers or listeners comply with the order to cover their mouth and nose.    Outdoor amusement parks  Amusement parks may operate at up to 30%. occupancy.    Libraries  Possibility to make collections available, provided that no more than 1 person per 15 mÂ² is present in the library, with the exception of librarians. Before entering the library, information about the limit of people should be posted.    Conducting activities by public and scientific libraries consisting in the organization of meetings and events is allowed indoors, provided that:    while maintaining a distance of 1.5 m between participants;    that participants comply with the obligation to cover their mouth and nose.    Night clubs, discos and other places available for dancing  Nightclubs, discos and other places to dance have closed.    Fairs, exhibitions, congresses, conferences  Trade fairs, congresses and conferences can be organized within the limit - 1 person per 15 m2.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220214181845/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/przyjazd-do-polski-spoza-strefy-schengen

25/2/22  Restrictions apply to unvaccinated people only.    Attention! The 30% limit does not include those vaccinated against COVID-19 provided that they show:    EU digital COVID certificate;  or a certificate of vaccination, test result and recovery.  If the indicated documents are not presented, the entrepreneur has the right to refuse to provide services.    Assembly  All types of meetings may be attended by up to 100 people. Participants are required to keep 1.5 m away from other people. In addition, the distance between assemblies must not be less than 100 m.    Meetings  Up to 100 people can participate in outdoor events and meetings, either in the premises or in a dedicated social area . There is a distance between the tables (every second table can be occupied, the distance between the tables must be at least 1.5 m - unless there is a partition at least 1 m high between them, counting from the surface of the table) .    Weddings, communions, consolations and other celebrations  You can organize special events outside and inside (e.g. in a restaurant). There is a limit of people - max. 100. Such events could take place in strict sanitary regime. There is a distance between the tables (every second table can be occupied, the distance between the tables must be at least 1.5 m - unless there is a partition at least 1 m high between them, counting from the surface of the table) .    https://web.archive.org/web/20220204133826/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/zgromadzenia-i-imprezy

25/2/22  There are no stay at home requirements.  Mask wearing in public and social distancing are required.    Social distance and face masks  Restrictions on movement  1.5 meters - the minimum distance between pedestrians  Obligation to maintain a distance of at least 1.5 meters between pedestrians.    The following are excluded from this obligation:    parents with children requiring care (up to 13 years of age),  people living together or running a farm,  people with a disability certificate, people with a disability degree, people with a certificate of need for special education, people who are unable to move independently and their guardians.  Covering the mouth and nose only with a mask  Covering the mouth and nose in confined spaces is mandatory throughout the country.  Only cover the nose and mouth with a mask. Scarves, visors and dishes are not allowed because they do not fulfill their primary function, i.e. they do not protect against the virus!    The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / customer service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, clinic, hospital, massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  in schools and universities during breaks between lessons and classes, unless otherwise decided by the head of the entity.  Where do you not need to cover your mouth and nose?    In the open air, in the forest, park, greenery, botanical gardens, historic gardens, on roads and squares, in cemeteries, promenades, boulevards, parking places for vehicles, forest parking lots, in family allotments and on the beach, and during private travel by car, motorcycle, quadricycle, moped, at the workplace to eat.     Detailed information on covering the mouth and nose as well as information on exceptions to this rule can be found in the regulation .    Important! Only persons with a medical certificate or a document confirming:    pervasive development disorders,  mental disorders,  moderate, severe or severe intellectual disability,  difficulty uncovering or covering your mouth or nose on your own.  advanced neurological, respiratory or circulatory disorders with respiratory or circulatory failure.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220206100800/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/dystans-spoleczny-i-maseczki

4/3/22  Rules for travelers coming to Poland from outside the European Union and from outside the Schengen area  Mandatory COVID-19 tests  People traveling from outside the European Union, from outside the Schengen area, must show a negative COVID-19 test result. You must complete the test regardless of the way in which you travel (collective, individual or on foot). Failure to test will require quarantine.    The obligation to perform the test also applies to vaccinated people or convalescents!    The test result must not be more than 24 hours prior to arrival.  The test can be performed at some airports in Poland - before border clearance or 3 hours after arrival (counting from border clearance).  quarantine   Attention! Persons crossing the Polish-Ukrainian border due to an armed conflict in Ukraine are not currently subject to the obligation to quarantine entry.    You are not quarantined if your antigen or PCR test is negative  and you meet one of the following conditions :    you are vaccinated with the full vaccination course:  a vaccine that is authorized in the European Union or is included in the list of vaccine equivalents authorized for marketing in the territory of the Republic of Poland, kept by the National Institute of Public Health PZH - National Research Institute,  14 days have elapsed since the administration of the last dose of vaccination (counted from the day following the administration of the last dose),  vaccination is certified by the EU COVID Certificate or another document in Polish or English confirming the vaccination.  You have been infected with the SARS-CoV-2 virus (you are the so-called healer):  not later than 6 months before the day of crossing the PR border,  you have a document that confirms the presence of the disease, issued in Polish or English, including the EU COVID Certificate .  You are subject to other exemptions listed in Â§ 3 of the Regulation of the Council of Ministers of May 6, 2021 on the establishment of certain restrictions, orders and bans in connection with the occurrence of an epidemic.  Who is exempt from showing COVID-19 test results when arriving from outside the Schengen area?       Important! If you do not submit a negative test result, you must go into quarantine for  7 days .      What test can I do?    before crossing the border: RT-PCR or antigenic.  Tests are not publicly funded.    Important!     Persons who, after arriving from outside the Schengen area, the EU, stay in the territory of the Republic of Poland for no longer than 24 hours and have a flight ticket confirming departure from the territory of the Republic of Poland within 24 hours, may be exempt from the obligation to undergo quarantine, provided that:    show a negative result of the SARS-CoV-2 test (antigenic, PCR) performed within 24 hours before arrival to the Republic of Poland,  perform such a test before the border check (applies only to airports where it is possible),  perform the test at the airport after the border check within 3 hours.  Traveler Location Card  Each person who crosses the state border of the Republic of Poland by plane fills in the Traveler Location Card in an electronic form before check-in . If this is not possible, fill it in on a paper form provided by the cabin crew.    The data administrator is the state poviat sanitary inspector (sanepid) competent for the place of residence or stay of the traveler.    EU COVID Certificate  The EU COVID Certificate is issued by the Ministry of Health. A vaccination certificate is issued:    in electronic form,  in paper form;  by providers of immunization against COVID-19,  by a primary care physician or primary care nurse.  Detailed information on the  EU COVID Certificate .    Also check the  Border Guard website for information on quarantine after crossing the border.    Important! This communication is provided for information purposes only and cannot be used as a basis for adjudicating on a case-by-case basis. The verification on the basis of the document presented for inspection and the final decision on quarantine or grounds for exemption from such a requirement will be taken by a Border Guard officer who performs border control.    In disputed / doubtful / random matters regarding sanitary restrictions / quarantine / vaccinations - including the rules for exemptions, shortening its duration - the only competent authority is the State (Border) Sanitary Inspector at the local level, or a higher level authority, i.e. the Minister responsible for Health (Chief Sanitary Inspector).    https://web.archive.org/web/2/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/przyjazd-do-polski-spoza-strefy-schengen
