25/2/22  Change in policy. Test are now available for anyone at a pharmacy without prior registration    How to get a coronavirus test at a pharmacy  No signups, no long waiting times and free of charge - now you can get tested at the pharmacy if you are concerned that you have the coronavirus. Check in which pharmacies near you can make it and on what terms!    In the pharmacy, you can do an antigen test:    without prior registration;  free;  unlimited - as many times as you need,  fast - the result after only a dozen or so minutes!  How to do it  Come to the pharmacy where the tests are performed - but be careful! Not every pharmacy participates in the program. Find out where the nearest pharmacy that runs the tests is .  The pharmacist will take a swab.  After a dozen or so minutes, you will receive the result and the pharmacist will enter it in the system.  You can also find information about the result on the Internet Patient Account and in the mojeIKP application .  Test results  If your score is:    negative - you will receive the EU COVID Certificate after the antigen test (valid for 48 hours),  positive - you will start home insulation .  Information on how long your isolation will last and certificates can be found on the Internet Patient Account and in the mojeIKP application .    Attention! Antigen tests are carried out in pharmacies. After a negative antigen test result, you can generate an EU COVID Certificate (UCC), but it will only be valid for 48 hours .    If you fall ill with the coronavirus and confirm the disease with the antigen test, you will not get the convalescent status and the EU COVID Certificate after 10 days!    Recover status confirmed by UCC can only be obtained after confirming the disease with  a PCR test performed at the collection point . Check how to sign up for a test at a download point .      https://web.archive.org/web/20220204154012/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/zapisz-sie-na-test-na-koronawirusa

Limited contact tracing in place.    I was in close contact with a person who tested positive. Should I report it somewhere?  If you are in close contact with a person infected with the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus (this person has obtained a confirmed, positive PCR test for SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus infection), report this fact to the sanitary inspection. Use the online form: Application for quarantine or isolation by the Sanepid.    If you have questions about quarantine, please call the hotline to contact the sanitary inspection : +48 22 25 00 115. The  hotline is open 24 hours a day.    Important! If you know you have been in close contact with an infected or sick person, stay home - even if you have not yet decided to quarantine, and you are feeling well. Avoid contact with other people. You can infect them if you find out that you are infected. If this is not possible, use all required personal protective equipment.    Attention! If you have been vaccinated for COVID-19, you will not be placed in quarantine. The rule applies from December 28, 2020.    However, from December 15, family  members of people suffering from COVID19 must undergo a coronavirus test, regardless of the certificate they have.    https://archive.fo/wXmsk

25/2/22  No change in policy    Social distance and face masks  Restrictions on movement  1.5 meters - the minimum distance between pedestrians  Obligation to maintain a distance of at least 1.5 meters between pedestrians.    The following are excluded from this obligation:    parents with children requiring care (up to 13 years of age),  people living together or running a farm,  people with a disability certificate, people with a disability degree, people with a certificate of need for special education, people who are unable to move independently and their guardians.  Covering the mouth and nose only with a mask  Covering the mouth and nose in confined spaces is mandatory throughout the country.  Only cover the nose and mouth with a mask. Scarves, visors and dishes are not allowed because they do not fulfill their primary function, i.e. they do not protect against the virus!    The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / customer service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, clinic, hospital, massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  in schools and universities during breaks between lessons and classes, unless otherwise decided by the head of the entity.  Where do you not need to cover your mouth and nose?    In the open air, in the forest, park, greenery, botanical gardens, historic gardens, on roads and squares, in cemeteries, promenades, boulevards, parking places for vehicles, forest parking lots, in family allotments and on the beach, and during private travel by car, motorcycle, quadricycle, moped, at the workplace to eat.     Detailed information on covering the mouth and nose as well as information on exceptions to this rule can be found in the regulation .    Important! Only persons with a medical certificate or a document confirming:    pervasive development disorders,  mental disorders,  moderate, severe or severe intellectual disability,  difficulty uncovering or covering your mouth or nose on your own.  advanced neurological, respiratory or circulatory disorders with respiratory or circulatory failure.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220206100800/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/dystans-spoleczny-i-maseczki

In the open air, in the forest, park, greenery, botanical gardens, historic gardens, on roads and squares, in cemeteries, promenades, boulevards, parking places for vehicles, forest parking lots, in family allotments and on the beach, and during private travel by car, motorcycle, quadricycle, moped, at the workplace to eat.     Detailed information on covering the mouth and nose as well as information on exceptions to this rule can be found in the regulation .    Important! Only persons with a medical certificate or a document confirming:    pervasive development disorders,  mental disorders,  moderate, severe or severe intellectual disability,  difficulty uncovering or covering your mouth or nose on your own.  advanced neurological, respiratory or circulatory disorders with respiratory or circulatory failure.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220206100800/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/dystans-spoleczny-i-maseczki

4/3/22  From 1st March Rules have been relaxed and masks are now required indoors only.    Covering the mouth and nose only with a mask  Covering the mouth and nose in confined spaces is mandatory throughout the country.  Only cover the nose and mouth with a mask. Scarves, visors and dishes are not allowed because they do not fulfill their primary function, i.e. they do not protect against the virus!    The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / customer service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, clinic, hospital, massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  in schools and universities during breaks between lessons and classes, unless otherwise decided by the head of the entity.  Where do you not need to cover your mouth and nose?    In the open air, in the forest, park, greenery, botanical gardens, historic gardens, on roads and squares, in cemeteries, promenades, boulevards, parking places for vehicles, forest parking lots, in family allotments and on the beach, and during private travel by car, motorcycle, quadricycle, moped, at the workplace to eat.     Detailed information on covering the mouth and nose as well as information on exceptions to this rule can be found in the regulation .    https://web.archive.org/web/20220304082256/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/dystans-spoleczny-i-maseczki

We want as many people as possible to receive the preparation against Covid-19 in the shortest possible time. It is in the interest of all of us - the vaccine offers a real chance of recovery.    E-referral    This is the document that entitles you to have the vaccine. In most cases, it is generated automatically for people who can sign up for a vaccination. Only in some cases do patients report to the doctor for this document. This happens when a given person does not have a PESEL number, or in the case of specific patients with the indicated diseases - they are informed about it.    The e-referral is valid for 90 days, but don't hesitate. If you have the opportunity, sign up for the vaccination now!    Registration for vaccination    Anyone who has an e-referral can sign up for a vaccination. There are several ways to do this:    call the helpline 989,  register online via e-Registration,  send an SMS saying SzczepimySie to the number 880 333 333,  sign up directly at the vaccination point (preferably by phone),  use the drive-thru point .     https://web.archive.org/web/20220127030346/https://www.gov.pl/web/szczepimysie/jak-sie--zaszczepic

25/2/22  There are no mandates in place to date. There has been a proposal for certain categories to be vaccinated by 1st March to work in certain sectors. No Mandates

Are vaccinations voluntary?  Vaccination is voluntary, except for healthcare professionals, pharmacists, medical students and healthcare professionals who must be fully vaccinated by March 1, 2022. We encourage other people to vaccinate against COVID-19. The more people get vaccinated, the more effective protection against the coronavirus will be.     https://web.archive.org/web/2/https://www.gov.pl/web/szczepimysie/pytania-i-odpowiedzi

11.	The learning and teaching process in pre-school and daycare institutions shall take place according to the recommendations for pre-school institutions of NIPHK dated 20.01.2022.      12.	The learning and teaching process in all pre-university education institutions of all levels, as well as in daycare centres shall take place in accordance with the MEST Guidelines for the organization of the educational process in the conditions of the Covid-19 pandemic. The task forces of the educational institutions decide on the application of scenarios for the organization of the teaching process, depending on the situation in the institution and in the classrooms.    13.	The teaching process in public and private institutions of higher education, as well as in vocational and non-formal education institutions, can take place with physical presence provided that groups over 50 people are accommodated in no more than 50% of the space.     14.	Students must possess any of the evidence mentioned in point 4.1 or 4.2 in order to be allowed registration to the dormitory.    15.	Students in public and private university institutions must possess any of the evidence mentioned in point 4.1 or 4.2, in order to be allowed to enter the building of the institution.    16.	Staff in all public and private institutions of all levels of education, including preschool and daycare institutions, must possess any of the evidence mentioned in point 4.1 or 4.2, in order to be allowed to enter the institution building.     17.	The highest administrative officer, or equivalent position, of each institution according to points 14, 15 and 16, is obliged by decision to appoint one or more responsible persons who will control the possession of any of the evidence mentioned in point 4.1 or 4.2.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220315002518/https://msh.rks-gov.net/sq/https:/msh.rks-gov.net/sq/miratohen-masat-e-reja-kunder-covid-19-3/miratohen-masat-e-reja-kunder-covid-19-3/

4.	All employees of public institutions, central and local public enterprises, private businesses, organizations, as well as other entities, must possess one of the following evidence, in order to be allowed to enter the work premises:  4.1	Certificate of vaccination with at least two doses or one dose of Janssen vaccine against COVID-19;  4.2	Persons with medical evidence from a specialist in the relevant field that they have contraindications and are exempt from vaccination, must possess a negative RT-PCR test for COVID 19 not older than one week;    https://web.archive.org/web/20220315002518/https://msh.rks-gov.net/sq/https:/msh.rks-gov.net/sq/miratohen-masat-e-reja-kunder-covid-19-3/miratohen-masat-e-reja-kunder-covid-19-3/

22.	Outdoor gatherings and cultural events are allowed. The organizer is obliged to ensure the observation of measures, including the maintenance of a physical distance of 1 meter between persons and the presentation of evidence recorded in points 19.1 to 19.4, except participants under the age of 12, as well as the wearing of masks.    https://msh.rks-gov.net/sq/miratohen-masat-e-reja-kunder-covid-19-3/

F. [Restriction of public and private gatherings]     19.	Unless otherwise specified in this Decision, indoor gatherings of up to 50% of capacities (workshops, meetings, seminars, trainings or other gatherings) are allowed. Except those under the age of 12, participants are obliged to possess any of the evidence mentioned in points 19.1 to 19.4 in order to be allowed to enter these premises, and the organizer is obliged to provide a physical distance of one (1) meter between persons and check the relevant evidence, such as:      19.1	Certificate of vaccination with at least two doses or one dose of Janssen vaccine against COVID-19;  19.2	Persons with medical evidence issued by the specialist doctor of the respective field verifying that they have contraindications and are exempt from vaccination must present the negative RT-PCR test for COVID-19, which should not be older than 48 hours;  19.3	Single dose vaccination certificate, not older than one (1) month.  19.4	Evidence that the person has recovered from COVID-19 in the last 90 days (positive RT-PCR test issued in the last 21â90 days).    20.	Meetings of the Assembly and Government are allowed regardless of the number of persons, respecting the wearing of masks and maintaining the physical distance of 1 (one) meter between persons.      21.	The Emergency Operational Centre of the Ministry of Health may issue a special permit, exceeding 50% of capacities, for events of special importance in the function of public interest.    22.	Outdoor gatherings and cultural events are allowed. The organizer is obliged to ensure the observation of measures, including the maintenance of a physical distance of 1 meter between persons and the presentation of evidence recorded in points 19.1 to 19.4, except participants under the age of 12, as well as the wearing of masks.    23.	Religious ceremonies and rites are allowed to carry out their activity up to 50% of the utilizing capacity, provided that they possess any of the evidence according to points 19.1 to 19.4 in order to be allowed to enter the indoor spaces, in accordance with the relevant instruction, except participants under the age of 12.    https://msh.rks-gov.net/sq/miratohen-masat-e-reja-kunder-covid-19-3/

Transportation Options  Are commercial flights operating? Yes  Reduced levels of commercial flights are available, but schedules change frequently so we recommend you check with the airline and/or travel agency for regular updates.  Is public transportation operating? Yes  https://web.archive.org/web/20220314235006/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/
https://web.archive.org/web/20220314235006/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/

No more curfew     Movement Restrictions  Is a curfew in place? No.  For access to all public institutions, malls and dining inside restaurants, customers are obliged to possess evidence of vaccination, a negative PRC or rapid negative antigen test.  Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? No  Public transport is allowed to operate.  Taxis are allowed to work.  Wearing a mask is mandatory when indoors.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220314235006/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/    https://web.archive.org/web/20220314235006/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/

Entry and Exit Requirements  Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter? Yes  Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry? Varies (see below)  As of March 1, 2022, every person who enters Kosovo must produce one of the following:  Full vaccination certificate with two (2) doses (or a single-dose of Janssen vaccine) not exceeding more than 12 months after receiving the last dose;  Vaccination certificate with a single dose, together with a negative RT-PCR test for COVID-19, not older than 48 hours;  Evidence that the person has recovered from COVID-19 in the last 90 days (positive RT-PCR test issued in the last 21â90 days);  Evidence that the person has received the third / booster dose;  Evidence of negative RT-PCR test for COVID-19, not older than 48 hours;  This requirement does not apply to children under the age of 12. Children from 12 to 16 years of age must have a negative RT-PCR test not older than 48 hours.    Airlines, transit points, and destination countries impose a patchwork of different testing requirements and airlines may refuse boarding for some passengers (including U.S. citizens and Kosovo residents). Airlines have the sole authority to decide who they allow to board their aircraft. Generally, pre-travel testing is recommended.  Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry? Yes  The Pristina International Airport is open to travelers.  Check with the airlines, airports, and the U.S. Embassies located in your countries of transit to verify entry/exit requirements and be aware that they change frequently.    Quarantine Information  Are U.S. citizens required to quarantine? Yes â self quarantine.  Citizens of the Republic of Kosovo, as well as persons with temporary or permanent resident permits, who enter the Republic of Kosovo and do not possess the evidence required above and seek to enter the country are obliged to respect home quarantine for a period of seven (7) days from the entry into the territory of the Republic of Kosovo.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220314235006/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/

6.	Public and private institutions and other entities are obliged to keep hand sanitizers and an amount of face masks in accessible places at the entrance of the building and indoors.    7.	Public and private institutions, as well as other entities are obliged to place visible signs of the rules of conduct for protection from COVID-19 at the entrance of each building, including the sign prohibiting entry to the building without masks, respecting the distance of one (1) meter and promotional signs for vaccination according to the design of the Ministry of Health.      8.	Officials of public and private institutions and other entities are obliged to carry out disinfection and ventilation of indoor spaces.      9.	Wearing a mask covering the nose and mouth is mandatory in all cases when indoors.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220315002518/https://msh.rks-gov.net/sq/https:/msh.rks-gov.net/sq/miratohen-masat-e-reja-kunder-covid-19-3/miratohen-masat-e-reja-kunder-covid-19-3/

Russian government website can't be accessed due to military operation in Ukraine, but following measures have been put in place until april:    From October 25, 2021 to April 1, 2022, metropolitan enterprises must transfer to remote work:  at least 30 percent of the total number of employees;  all workers over 60 years of age and suffering from chronic diseases. An exception is only for employees whose presence in the workplace is critical to the functioning of the organization.    In addition, in organizations where possible, it is recommended to transfer the maximum number of people to a remote mode of work.    Russia's Labor Ministry has recommended that all enterprises send as many of their employees to remote work as possible due to the surge in Covid-19 cases.    Previous archives:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220220025511/https://www.mos.ru/city/projects/measures/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220218140404/https://tass.ru/obschestvo/13583061

Event organizers with less than 500 attendees are encouraged to make similar decisions.  Previous archive:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220220025511/https://www.mos.ru/city/projects/measures/

The government of the Russian Federation requires the use of masks in crowded public areas, including public transportation, taxis, parking lots, and elevators. This order applies to the entire country.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220221231511/https://ru.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Russian government website can't be accessed due to military operation in Ukraine, but following measures have been put in place until april:    People above 60 in Moscow must stay at home or in their country house. They can go out only in these cases: when they need to go to the store, walk their pets, take out the trash, go to work, to the clinic or hospital, take a walk or play sports in the fresh air. They may also leave the house if there is a direct threat to life and health. These measures do not apply to those who have had COVID-19, as well as those who have been vaccinated against coronavirus.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220220025511/https://www.mos.ru/city/projects/measures/

Aeroflot accepts passengers for carriage on flights between airports in the Russian Federation without checking medical documents related to Covid-19. However, a number of regions have regulations on the stay and/or self-isolation of arriving passengers.    https://archive.ph/IXqpX

On 18 March 2020 the Russian government introduced restrictions on entry into the whole country for almost all foreign citizens. On 30 March 2020, temporary restrictions on entry and exit via Russiaâs land borders were enforced. The duration of these remains unspecified.    These restrictions were eased on 16 April 2021 for nationals and permanent residents of certain countries including the UK. They may now travel to Russia by air via authorised 3rd countries. The full list is subject to change and currently includes Albania; Andorra; Argentina; Armenia; Austria; Azerbaijan; Bahamas; Bahrain; Bangladesh; Belgium; Brazil; Bulgaria; China; Columbia; Costa Rica; Croatia; Cuba; Cyprus; Czech Republic; Denmark; Djibouti; Dominican Republic; Egypt; Ethiopia; Finland; France; Germany; Greece; Hungary; Iceland; India; Iran; Iraq; Italy; Japan; Jordan; Kazakhstan; Kenya; Kuwait; Kyrgyzstan; Lebanon; Lichtenstein; Luxemburg; Maldives; Malta; Mauritius; Mexico; Moldova; Mongolia; Morocco; Netherlands; New Zealand; North Macedonia; Norway; Oman; Peru; Portugal; Qatar; Republic of Ireland; Republic of Korea; Republic of Seychelles; Saudi Arabia; Serbia; Singapore; Slovakia; Slovenia; Spain, Sri-Lanka; Sweden; Switzerland; Syria; Tajikistan; Thailand; Tunisia; Turkey; United Arab Emirates; United Kingdom.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220307230828/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/russia/entry-requirements

Any citizen of the Russian Federation over the age of 18 can register for the vaccination. The Russian government has approved three domestically developed and produced vaccines for use in the country including Sputnik V, EpiVacCorona, and CoviVac. Additionally, service companies are required to vaccinate at least 80 percent of the total number of employees by January 1, 2022. Vaccination with the first component must be carried out before December 1, 2021. These measures were introduced by the decision of the chief sanitary doctor for the city of Moscow.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220307230219/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/russia/coronavirus

Russian government website can't be accessed due to military operation in Ukraine, but following measures have been put in place until april:    People above 60 in Moscow must stay at home or in their country house. They can go out only in these cases: when they need to go to the store, walk their pets, take out the trash, go to work, to the clinic or hospital, take a walk or play sports in the fresh air. They may also leave the house if there is a direct threat to life and health. These measures do not apply to those who have had COVID-19, as well as those who have been vaccinated against coronavirus.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220220025511/https://www.mos.ru/city/projects/measures/

The Authorities of the Republic of San Marino issued Decree-Law no. 3 of 14 January 2022 - Strengthening of provisions to avoid the spread of the COVID-19 virus. The provisions of the aforementioned Decree-Law, ratified by Decree-Law no. 6 of 21 January 2022, unless otherwise provided for, shall apply until the end of the health emergency, which is currently extended until 30 April 2022.         Entry into the Republic of San Marino, for those coming from countries other than Italy and the Vatican City, or who have stayed outside these two countries in the previous 14 days, is permitted on presentation of the following documents:         A certificate of vaccination against SARS-CoV-2* or a certificate of recovery from SARS-CoV-2 within the previous six months. This certificate may be in paper or digital form;  Or    A negative coronavirus test certificate following a molecular or antigenic swab taken no later than 48 hours before entry and in any case in accordance with the health protocols in force in the Republic of San Marino. Any molecular swab taken within 48 hours prior to entry into the territory of the Italian Republic is considered valid for those who do not fall within the cases referred to in letter a) above.        Children under ten years of age are exempt from submitting the certificates referred to in letters a) and b).    https://web.archive.org/web/2021*/https://www.esteri.sm/pub2/EsteriSM/en/Covid/Covid.html

All retail stores may remain open 24 hours, seven days a week. No changes. Cafes, bars, and restaurants may now operate outdoor facilities with no closing time.  Indoor facilities may operate until 1:00 a.m.  Music is now allowed. All retail stores may remain open 24 hours, seven days a week. All operating facilities must provide a minimum of 9 m2 per person. Exceptions are fitness centers, spa centers, gyms, and similar facilities which must provide 16 m2 per person.  This number includes the staff at these businesses. Up to 500 people are allowed to meet indoors or outdoors. Sports events may have spectators of up to 50% capacity in outdoor stadiums or 30% capacity in indoor arenas. Graduation celebrations are allowed. Events expecting over 500 people must get permission from the Crisis Response Team. Recreational classes and excursions may take place with consent from the Ministry of Education an competent institutions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220307214010/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

Starting December 20, 2020 the Government of Serbia is reporting that foreigners seeking to enter Serbia will need to provide a negative PCR test, not older than 48 hours. These measures are reported to not apply to several categories of travelers, including:  Foreign citizens in transit, with 12 hours allowed between entry to and exit from Serbia.  Minors up to 12 years of age, provided the parent, custodian or any other person accompanying the minor has a negative PCR test, if it is needed.  Crew and cabin crew of aircraft whose final destination is Serbia.  Crew, personnel, and passengers in transit through Serbiaâs international airports.  Accredited staff of foreign diplomatic and consular missions, as well as offices of international organizations. Also included are family members with diplomatic status in Serbia. Foreign citizens who have been granted temporary residence or permanent residence in Serbia.  As of July 24, 2021 the Government of Serbia is reporting that foreign citizens may enter Serbia without a negative COVID-19 test if they possess proof of recovery from COVID-19 at least 14 days prior to their entry and no more than 6 months prior to their entry.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220307214010/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

No change.    A supplementary budget with new support measures was adopted in April 2021. New measures include: (i) wage subsidies, including payment of Â½ of minimum wages for all entrepreneurs and employees in SMEs and large companies for three months (RSD 69.8 billion); (ii) additional payments for employees in travel, hospitality, and art (RSD 4.4 billion); (iii) universal cash transfer of EUR 60 to each citizen over 18 years old, paid in two installments of EUR 30 eachâin May and November (RSD 43.2 billion);(iv) a one-off payment of EUR 50 to all pensioners (RSD 10 billion);(v)a one-off financial assistance of EUR 60 to all the unemployed, paid in June (RSD 4.3 billion); and (vi) support for the transport sector and for city hotels (RSD 3.9bn); and a one-off payment of EUR 25 to all vaccinated citizens (RSD 9 billion). The total estimated cost amounts to 2.5 percent of GDP. It also includes additional healthcare spending and increased public investment (2 percent of GDP), mostly in infrastructure, environmental protection, and defense. The existing scheme for state guaranteed bank loans to SMEs has been expanded by EUR 500 million (1 percent of GDP) and a new EUR 500 million scheme for vulnerable companies has been established.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220307220224/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

In February 2021, the NBS and the ECB agreed to extend the duration of the precautionary repo line with the ECB to address possible euro liquidity needs of Serbian financial institutions. The repo line, initially planned to last until end-June 2021, has been extended for nine months, until end-March 2022.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220307220224/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

During their stay in public places indoors, citizens are obliged to wear protective masks and maintain a distance of at least two meters between two persons who do not reside in the same household, in order to prevent the spread of the infectious disease COVID-19.    In public places in the open, if it is not possible to maintain a distance of at least two meters between two people (in front of shops, pharmacies, bus and other stops, etc.), wearing protective masks is mandatory. It is obligatory to wear protective masks in public road and rail transport of passengers. Parents of minor children or children with special needs, ie their guardians, are obliged to ensure that children older than four years wear a protective mask in the cases referred to in para. 1â3. of this article.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220307222130/https://www.propisi.net/uredbu-o-merama-za-sprecavanje-i-suzbijanje-zarazne-bolesti-covid-19/

No changes. The school traffic light system is in place. Based on the current valid rules, if there is an infected pupil in the classroom, the principal will decide on closing the entire classroom. The only exception to self-isolation will be for children vaccinated against Covid or those recently recovered from Covid. An entire school may be closed in special cases, but this will depend on the discussion with regional hygienists. Schoolchildren are required to wear masks during school, while their parents can test them with antigen tests.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220321204905/https://www.minedu.sk/skolsky-semafor/

Since February 5th, employers are no longer obliged to prevent those who are unvaccinated from entering workplaces; employers are still recommended to provide voluntary testing for employees.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220321205138/https://korona.gov.sk/opatrenia-pre-vstup-zamestnancov-na-pracovisko-zamestnavatela/

No changes. All mass event attendees must be fully vaccinated; those who are unvaccinated must have proof of full COVID-19 recovery within the past 90 days. Mass events can now go ahead under strict restrictions. Events have been categorised into low, medium and high risk:  - Low risk: capacity of 100 or 50% of venue maximum capacity. Defined as events where participants are wearing masks, food and drinks are prohibited, sitting is mandatory, and event takes place without singing, encouragement or other loud vocal expressions.  - Medium risk: capacity of 100 or 25% of venue maximum capacity. Defined as events where participants are wearing masks and here is a fixed sitting or standing arrangement.   - High risk: capacity of 20 people. Defined as events in a public catering operation or a non-low-risk mass event and a medium-risk mass event; this includes weddings, parties and other celebrations.   Funerals are exempt from these restrictions, as are meetings of public authorities, elections, and mass events necessary for the course of the following professional competitions in selected sports.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220321210456/https://korona.gov.sk/wp-content/uploads/2021/12/en-facilities-and-mass-events_20211125.pdf

This means that all mass events, in addition to operating in the base mode, can take place from 14 March without capacity or other organizational restrictions and conditions. The obligation to wear a respirator at mass events remains in place, including outdoor mass events.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220321210725/https://korona.gov.sk/obmedzenia-pre-hromadne-podujatia/

No change. Gatherings of more than 6 are prohibited unless from the same household, or attending an officially organised mass event.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220321210456/https://korona.gov.sk/wp-content/uploads/2021/12/en-facilities-and-mass-events_20211125.pdf

Workers in healthcare and social care institutions and in prisons are required to comply by the "RVT - recovered, vaccinated, or tested" rule to enter workplaces. This has been relaxed, with previously more places of work having to abide by this rule.  - Recovery must be proved via a positive PCR result in the last 180 days  - An individual is considered vaccinated from the day of their vaccination, and onwards.  - Tests can either be in the form of a rapid antigen test conducted in the last 48 hours or a PCR test conducted in the last 72 hours.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220309170133/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/measures-to-contain-the-spread-of-covid-19-infections/

Following easing of almost all restrictions on the 22nd of February, there is no longer any restrictions on public events taking place, though masks are recommended at outdoor events where 1.5m social distancing is not possible.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220309170902/https://www.total-slovenia-news.com/politics/9624-slovenia-ends-almost-all-covid-restrictions-except-masks

Public transport is running as usual. The use of masks is mandatory for drivers and passengers over 6 years of age. Cable-cars on ski slopes are also running, with windows opening an a 1.5m distance rule observed whilst queuing and using the cable-cars.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220309170133/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/measures-to-contain-the-spread-of-covid-19-infections/

Fully open, with a mask mandate for all passengers over 6 years old and all drivers.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220325163253/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/measures-to-contain-the-spread-of-covid-19-infections/

As of 19 February 2022, a person who has been in close contact with a person who tested positive in a coronavirus test will no longer have to quarantine at home. People who are ill are recommended to stay home.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220309165115/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/
People who are ill are told to stay home. People who have come into close contact with a positive case are no longer required to quarantine

No restrictions in place.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220325163253/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/measures-to-contain-the-spread-of-covid-19-infections/

All travellers arriving in Slovenia will no longer be required to present proof of vaccination or a negative COVID-19 test. All travellers arriving in Slovenia must continue to complete the Digital Passenger Locator Form 24 hours before arrival, if entering via an airport or a ferry terminal. The form is not required if entering overland at a border crossing.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220309171748/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/slovenia/entry-requirements & http://web.archive.org/web/20220309171842/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/border-crossing/

Tests are no longer generally available for free. Free testing with a rapid antigen test and a rapid antigen test for self-testing has been abolished and the government budget will only pay for testing with a rapid antigen test for activities where this is still required, such as entering health or social care institutions, and prisons. Due to high demand, PCR tests are limited to those who have had a negative rapid test result and are advised by their doctor to get a PCR test due to showing symptoms or coming into contact with someone with a positive result.  Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20220309165115/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/

Tests are no longer generally available for free. Free testing with a rapid antigen test and a rapid antigen test for self-testing has been abolished and the government budget will only pay for testing with a rapid antigen test for activities where this is still required, such as entering health or social care institutions, and prisons. Due to high demand, PCR tests are limited to those who have had a negative rapid test result and are advised by their doctor to get a PCR test due to showing symptoms or coming into contact with someone with a positive result.  Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20220309165115/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/

Free testing with a rapid antigen test and a rapid antigen test for self-testing is abolished. The government budget will only pay for testing with a rapid antigen test for activities where this is still required. Such activities include:  - Users of hospital and other healthcare services   - Persons who wish to discontinue their self-isolation between days 7 and 10 after testing positive  - Persons with proof of a positive rapid-antigen self-test result   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220325163253/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/measures-to-contain-the-spread-of-covid-19-infections/ & http://web.archive.org/web/20220325163718/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/

People are encouraged via the government website to download the #OstaniZdrav mobile application, which is intended to record contact between people who have installed the application on their mobile phones. After contact, the application displays a low or high risk of COVID-19 transmission, with application status updated every 4 hours. This has been designed to encourage citizens to behave more responsibly.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220309180516/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/the-ostanizdrav-mobile-application/

Surgical mask II or IIR or a FFP2 or a FFP3 mask are mandatory in all closed public spaces and on public transport. Protective masks are recommended in open public spaces or outside if a distance of at least 1.5 metres is not possible to maintain.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220309170133/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/measures-to-contain-the-spread-of-covid-19-infections/

Vaccines are available for those age 12 and older. AstraZeneca, Moderna, and Pfizer-BioNTech vaccines are all available. Vaccination is free of charge and is provided to all those who have permanent or temporary residence in the Republic of Slovenia, regardless of whether they are insured.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220309181259/https://www.gov.si/teme/koronavirus-sars-cov-2/cepljenje-proti-covid-19/

1st April 2022 onwards, the remaining official recommendations will be removed or adapted to the rate of transmission, the burden on health care services, and vaccination rates at that time. After that, the vaccination recommendation will remain in place, along with specific recommendations for health service and care environments.    The new measures include the removal of participants limits in public gatherings and events, abolishing maximum group sizes in eating and drinking establishments, shopping centers, private gatherings and tournaments.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220319142922/https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/news/travelling-to-sweden-entry-rules-restrictions-explained/

Non-fully vaccinated travellers, e.g., unaccompanied minors, the partly vaccinated, or travellers with medical exemptions, are not exempted. The exemption is entirely connected to the vaccine certificate, not of country of residence or citizenship,    The list of approved countries in Sweden consists of:    Albania  Andorra  Armenia  Cabo Verde  El Salvador  Faroe Islands  Georgia  Israel  Lebanon  Morocco  Moldova  Monaco  Montenegro  New Zeeland  North Macedonia  Panama  San Marino  Serbia  Singapore  Switzerland  Taiwan  Thailand  Togo  Tunisia  Turkey  Ukraine  United Arab Emirates  The UK + Guernsey, Isle of Man and Jersey  Uruguay  USA  Vatican    The new measures include the removal of participants limits in public gatherings and events, abolishing maximum group sizes in eating and drinking establishments, shopping centers, private gatherings and tournaments.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220319142922/https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/news/travelling-to-sweden-entry-rules-restrictions-explained/

25/3/22  COVID-19 vaccines if you live in Tajikistan  We will update this page when the Government of Tajikistan announces new information on the national vaccination programme. You can sign up to get email notifications when this page is updated.    The Tajikistan national vaccination programme started in March 2021 and is using the AstraZeneca, Janssen (Johnson and Johnson) and Sinovac vaccines. The Tajikistan authorities have stated that British nationals resident in Tajikistan are eligible for vaccination if they choose to join the programme. Further information is available on the Ministry of Health website    https://web.archive.org/web/20220325182905/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/tajikistan/coronavirus

3 September 2021    ISTANBUL, Sept. 3 (Xinhua) -- Turkish physicians on Friday hailed the country's decision to vaccinate children 12 years and older against COVID-19 as schools prepare to open next week.    Turkish Health Minister Fahrettin Koca announced Thursday that all children aged 12 years and up would be allowed to get the jabs.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220317153103/http://www.news.cn/english/2021-09/03/c_1310166774.htm
